A sumptuously realised detective mystery that merges Holmesian deductions with shootouts, explosions and action sequences -- some of which are shown with slow-motion bravado.
Having spent much of his career filtering good humour through very bad taste, writer-director Pang Ho-cheung delivers arguably his naughtiest picture to date with a pitch-black comedy.
Visually inventive yet dramatically lacking.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Takashi Miike's live-action adaptation of the long-running anime series Nintama Rantaro is a hilarious family movie that will handsomely reward younger viewers and fans of the original, but might inevitably alienate the uninitiated.
Sadly, the film also seems to be in a race with its ensemble cast to see which will first lose its sanity completely -- and the film wins by a fraction.
movie_title: Hi, Fidelity (Cheut gwai dik nui yan) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A relentlessly sweet and entertaining urban rom-com.
movie_title: Don't Go Breaking My Heart (Daan gyun naam yu) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Yu's increasingly sombre portrait of loyalty and violent revenge is partly let down by his story's uniformly superficial characterisation.
Sufficiently diverting yet predictable enough to be just the perfect fodder for genre cinema enthusiasts.
The soul of this movie is really in its tireless references to the historical and social conditions of 1950s and 60s Hong Kong, whose street views are recreated in vibrant, saturated colours.
It is at once loyal to the Hong Kong director's aesthetic sensibilities and the myriad of martial arts traditions that he's gone to exhaustive length to pay homage to.
A relentlessly entertaining romancer.
This hand-drawn animated feature by first-time directors Christian Desmares and Franck Ekinci is a steampunk marvel that will enchant both kids and adults with its high-concept premise.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In Tsui's hands, the communist propaganda classic becomes a handy platform to showcase his craftsmanship.
Should any pop star wish to stroke his own ego by leaping into the film director's seat, he could at least handle it more subtly than Richie Jen does with this fawning debut.
movie_title: All You Need Is Love (Luo pao ba ai qing) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing tale of crime and non-punishment set after the bursting of Japan's bubble economy.
You don't want to be in Adam Sandler's shoes right now.

The heartening story of a young girl realising her singing talent is tempered by the borderline offensive portrayal of her deaf and mute farming parents ... as a pair of clowns that serve as the butt of most jokes.
This poor man's Whiplash never quite conveys the depths of its protagonists' struggles.
This rom-com ... is so hackneyed it might be more fun counting the cliches than cheering for its male lead, now stranded light years away from his former James Bond glow.
This entertaining Bollywood musical is so relentlessly buoyant in its charge to ask the big questions it comes close to reaching an epiphany.
Considering the star power of its two leads, it is a pity that this film wasn't conceived as more of a two-hander.
movie_title: A Tale of Three Cities (San cheng ji) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While Wu's pop cultural spoofs are largely hit-and-miss ... his creativity fades as Undercover Duet gradually ditches its Hong Kong setting to become a mediocre Shanghai-set action thriller.
As strands of storyline feverishly tie themselves up through twists and coincidences, the double and triple crosses fade in impact next to the poise of Choi's all-star cast.
The fight scenes ... are staged in the filmmaker's typically professional fashion, and the thrilling car chases in populated areas flaunt a blissful ignorance of civilian casualties.
The importance of ageing gracefully is examined with both humour and pain in the sharply observed While We're Young, a satire that's more brutally honest than it is impertinent.
This existentialist meditation on free will and murderous impulses may be worthy of Kafka or Camus ... One of the most perversely original fantasy movies in recent memory.
movie_title: Attack on Titan: Part 1 (Shingeki no kyojin) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Assassin summons a strangely rapturous experience from its ostensibly bewildering narrative, which only adds to the air of mystique. An instant classic.
A hot-blooded movie with a sophisticated view of the high-pressure pursuits of pro riders.
This vampire parody transcends its one-joke nature to yield extended hilarity.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This spirited movie is a tour de force in bringing enchanting form to abstract ideas.
Paris is where broken hearts go to heal - or so this insipid travel commercial of a film would like us to infer from its sporadically amusing, though never remotely credible, romantic story.
Monster Hunt is far more engaging as cultural commentary than as entertainment.
The second English-language feature by Amélie's Jean-Pierre Jeunet is a road movie that has captured its visually striking journey in glorious 3D.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A stately backstage drama that gradually morphs into a full-blown supernatural horror movie, [this is] a synthetic experience that sporadically intrigues but never fully engages.
Despite its origin as a shoujo manga (for teenage girls), this abridged version is incongruously at its weakest when it deals with matters of the heart.
Although screenwriter David Nicholls' seriously rushed, trimmed and modified adaptation has created large discrepancies with the book, this ... remains a strangely engrossing film.
Infinitely Polar Bear features an endearing turn by Mark Ruffalo and will bring a smile to your face.
It feels like a music video that refuses to end.
This gay-themed romance will likely break a few hearts with its devastating tale about finding one's place in the world.
This fourth instalment does well to supplement the 3D spectacle with lively characters and good humour.
A heartfelt production that should find its place in Hong Kong's stagnant prison movie tradition.
movie_title: Imprisoned: Survival Guide for Rich and Prodigal (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A San Francisco-set fantasy in which [Blake Lively] plays out a Benjamin Button-like existence through some truly awkward romantic situations.
An artfully presented film about two lovers who can't stop torturing themselves with their self-serving tendency and inexplicable aloofness.
For all its awkwardness in bridging the personal and the cultural, Front Cover does deliver as a nice little romantic comedy with a pair of endearing leads.
A genre mishmash that goes from exorcism drama to gangster comedy to zombie horror to supernatural romance. ... Nick Cheung has obviously done enough to set himself up for a sequel.
Its corny display of nationalist pride aside, Wu's superior sequel to the laughably scripted Wolf Warrior should at least satisfy genre audiences with its slam-bang action.
Few genre fans should feel short-changed by Yip's brutal action showcase.
It's a shame how the heavyweight cast and exotic European locations are wasted on such a derivative story.
This CGI spectacle largely transcends its genre clichés with its relentlessly earnest desire to please.
movie_title: Legend Of The Naga Pearls (Jiao Zhu Chuan) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from its allegory about power, Wu Kong as an effects-driven action fantasy is just not very entertaining.
Ozon has at least scored on one count: L'Amant Double is so gloriously and unpredictably kinky that it manages to make Fifty Shades of Grey look like child's play.

The best way to screen this might well be as an infomercial at sake conventions, where viewers are free to sample minutes-long clips set against an incessant soundtrack of bland, easy-listening music.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A wacky family comedy imbued with a touch of lazily scripted sci-fi fantasy that suggests it's pitched at pre-teens.
Hui makes the most of her cast - boasting a notable number of Hong Kong Film Awards winners - to fashion an unapologetically human drama.
Made in Hong Kong forms the first part of Fruit Chan Gor's "1997 Trilogy", and is shot with a rawness and urgency that would in time become the writer-director's signature.
Mad World is not quite the profound reflection of reality its makers intended it to be, but despite its flaws this is a brave film.

77 Heartbreaks, despite its peculiar premise, has nothing interesting to say about contemporary mating mores, although I was surprised -- and occasionally amused -- by its long line of supporting stars.
A respectable period action drama that frequently loses its steam to redundant scenes.

Shunning the crowd-pleasing, life-affirming tendencies of mainstream dance movies, Polina instead offers a lyrical and introspective look at the intricate process of finding one's true artistic calling.
A sensual and uncompromisingly heartbreaking account of a one-night stand that fizzles out into two lives of lingering regrets.
With Prisoners offers a nightmarish account of institutional depravity, one said by its makers to be based on real events.
MacLaine is the only reason this movie works.
A quirky yet predictable film made special by its reverence for inspired cooking, the directorial debut of Hong Kong editor Derek Hui is more food porn than romantic comedy.
movie_title: This Is Not What I Expected (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun, but a little frivolous.
The true-life medical drama is less likely to bring awareness to a very rare autoimmune disorder than it is to be consumed as a low-rent imitator of Safe, Todd Haynes' 1995 parable.
The Salesman is a meticulously plotted moral puzzle that, once again, shows how great art can transcend the deeply restrained culture it springs from.
This big-budget action comedy is so sloppily written and utterly derivative that it may struggle to register in your mind even before end credits roll.
While it's a tonally uneven and sometimes implausibly scripted popcorn movie, Love Contractually would have been far less gratifying if not for its pair of very pleasant leads.
Yau does an impressive job of keeping the audience engaged amid the barrage of car crashes, shoot-outs and explosions.
Fukada's film sidesteps easy catharsis to stage a serious, and quite emotionally intense, inquiry into the unknown shades of human nature.
The increasingly absurd societal values of post-handover Hong Kong receive rollicking parody treatment in The Sinking City: Capsule Odyssey, a vibrant and furiously funny comedy-thriller.
It'll likely take a diehard Hong fan to truly admire this dreamily scripted fare, lacking as it does the writer-director's usually rigorous musing on fate and perception.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A mellow look at the tragic ends of several veterans of the criminal underworld, Colour of the Game ... veers towards the violent fatalism that colours much of Johnnie To's work.
Revenge plots don't get more contrived and illogical than they do in this stylish yet unashamedly superficial homage to the spaghetti western subgenre.
While cringeworthy performances abound, the best surprise here is a supporting role for Hangover alumnus Mike Tyson.
For all its unabashed jingoism (including a South China Sea warning towards the end), the hellish displays of combat it includes hardly make for an advertisement to enlist.
An even more kid-friendly offering than before, [this] is a visually vibrant fantasy comedy that may disappoint viewers invested in the more thematically adventurous original.
You're not going to hear people talking plot twists or modern spins about this umpteenth take on Johanna Spyri's classic children's story. ... Handsomely crafted, if uncompromisingly old-fashioned.
Having eschewed the usual depictions of Wukong causing supernatural mayhem, The Monkey King 3 stands or falls on its musings about love in all its forms - and they're largely unsatisfying.
It is this adult fairy tale's uninhibited embrace of love in all its euphoric glory that renders The Shape of Water such an unexpected delight.
Youth's conflicted narrative conveys the loss of innocence of its young characters fascinatingly.
The supernatural murder mystery is crammed so full with dazzling visuals and convoluted exposition that viewers are advised to surrender to this fever dream - or give up entirely.
For all the shape-shifting antics and giant fantasy creatures that it throws at the audience, Dunjia is only ever as fun as its characters get.
Regular viewers of serial killer dramas - from Se7en to all those Death Note movies - may feel like they've seen it all before.
movie_title: The Liquidator (Xinli Zui Zhi Chengshi Zhi Guang) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While far from being coherent, actress-turned director Sandra Ng's first feature does boast enough scenes of inspired hilarity to offset its less effective moments.
This time-travelling romance by Hsieh Chun-yi strikes an unexpectedly poignant chord beneath its teen comedy facade.
The White Girl is at once a self-proclaimed love letter to Hong Kong and an inadvertent middle finger to the art of sensible screenwriting.
[It] is ultimately more memorable for the chilling performances of its trio of actresses than for its story, which turns into a spectacle of family dysfunction and moral depravity.
movie_title: The Bold, the Corrupt, and the Beautiful (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While [Chrissie] Chau has given one of her most delicate performances to date, it is [Joyce] Cheng who steals the show with a heart-melting display of joy and compassion.
Tightly paced and at times overly melodramatic, Woo's film is a ridiculous but very enjoyable action thriller.
It's just too bad that this waterlogged thriller is as technically impressive as it is narratively dubious.
[The film] does manage to blend romantic comedy, sport film tropes and ensemble human drama into a pleasant if mostly unsurprising whole.
Singer-actress Stephy Tang has never commanded the screen to quite the extent she does in this karate-themed character drama.
Dealer/Healer is by turns a violent action movie, a buddy comedy, a cheesy romance and even a terminal disease drama - and never finds the right tone for this schizophrenic mix.
The world of high finance makes an awkward crossover into the realm of soft-core sex romp with this curious dud from producer Ng Kin-hung.
The extreme measures by which Japanese politicians and bureaucrats rise through the ranks are ruthlessly satirised in this hilariously over-the-top high-school electoral drama.
movie_title: Teiichi: Battle of Supreme High (Teiichi no kuni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While it doesn't tell the most entertaining of stories, the meandering drama does slowly reveal itself to be a powerful statement on suicide prevention.
Chasing the Dragon will be remembered more as a Donnie Yen showcase than a Crippled Ho biopic.
Fireworks merely proves an ill-advised endeavour to tweak the original drama's musings on early adolescent desire and small quirks of luck into a full-on fantasy romance.
movie_title: Fireworks, Should We See It from the Side or the Bottom? (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although The Tag-Along 2 is short of creative scares, the film qualifies as more than passable entertainment with its tightly woven storylines and strong performances.
movie_title: The Tag-Along 2 (Hong yi xiao nu hai 2) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The raw emotions of young love are captured in alternately ecstatic and frustrating fashion in Drowning Love, based on George Asakura's eponymous manga series.
[The film is] far more effective as a satire on [the] milieu of seductive internet idols and their desperate fans than as an espionage spoof.
An adequate homage to the comedic tradition immortalised by Mr Vampire (1985) and its sequels.
movie_title: Vampire Cleanup Department (Gao geung jing dou fu) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If Watkins has done anything well, it's that he never pauses the action to consider the ridiculousness of it all.
While the film eventually settles on Kurosawa's favourite themes of familial breakdown and the evocative sway of evil, it is the queasy ambience that will stay with you long after it's all over.
Bittersweet should enchant foodies - although the film's tendency to pass gay stereotypes as humour may ruffle the feathers of more sensitive viewers.
All those thrilling set-pieces may leave one feeling a little hollow inside; but for action film buffs, Christmas has come early.
This post-Holocaust drama, while admittedly quite engrossing to watch, can't avoid coming across as overly streamlined to offer easy catharsis for a mainstream audience.
Never Gone will likely struggle to get the audience on the side of its infuriatingly fickle heroine despite an endearing turn by Crystal Liu.
There's no doubt Trine Dyrholm - named best actress at the 2016 Berlin Film Festival for her emotionally intense portrayal of Anna - owns the movie's best moments.
It'd be very hard to think of a more pointless reboot than writer-director Jeff Lau Chun-wai's A Chinese Odyssey Part Three.
At a time when fears of political inference in the ICAC's role as a guardian of rule of law in Hong Kong are growing, S Storm is not even good propaganda.
Neal Wu paints a sensitive portrait of the strains of a long-distance relationship, and the film offers an unexpectedly bleak account of how people can grow apart.
Erased's fragmented and convoluted narrative may give viewers the impression it is a patiently staged, grippingly told psychological mystery, but they soon discover what an illogical mess it is.
Night's Tightrope offers everything from vengeful schoolgirls and ghastly suicides to a relentlessly gloomy view of Japanese society to satisfy the fans of crime-fiction author Kanae Minato.
Toho's 29th entry in the Godzilla franchise may prove too talky for some, but still manages to pay loving homage to the lumbering anti-hero of Ishiro Honda's 1954 classic.
Benny Chan's best film in years - a Chinese wuxia epic with obvious echoes to classic spaghetti Western films and Akira Kurosawa's samurai dramas like Seven Samurai and Yojimbo.
Less a harrowing survival tale than a sweet-natured talking-animal cartoon for young children. ... This is pleasant but entirely frivolous fare.
This is that rare bromance movie in which the lads are less connected via women and drugs than by their intense, cerebral pursuits.
The best condition to consume this wacky action fantasy - not that you should feel obliged to - is intoxicated.
Audiences from any culture should be able to learn from some of the potentially world-changing ideas paraded in this informative feature.
Bounty Hunters is a Chinese-Korean espionage comedy that intermittently amuses but never comes across as being remotely plausible.
A slice-of-life drama in which very little happens, After the Storm derives great emotional resonance from the subtlest indications of family ties - or lack thereof.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A minor work by a master craftsman, Johnnie To's Three tells a haphazardly scripted and weirdly paced story with intermittent flashes of technical brilliance.
Cold War 2 is competently plotted, tautly edited and superbly acted across the board. This is a political thriller that deserves the billing.
It says much about the colourful characters, thrilling action and inventive visual effects that Chen Sicheng's odd-couple caper never gets tedious over its 135-minute duration.

While its high-concept story touches on everything from assisted suicide and parental absence, to the emptiness of material wealth, this very dark film is, at its core, a conventional romantic comedy.
Bi Gan's art-house gem is a narrative experiment which intuitively bridges social realism and magic realism to tell a story of great emotional resonance.
An elegant yet overly detached account of events leading up to Japan's unconditional surrender to the Allies on August 15, 1945. ... Non-history buffs probably need not apply.
There are enough cleavage and upskirt shots of young Japanese girls to satisfy a pervert's wettest dream. But ... Virgin Psychics is also seriously undermined by its dreadful storytelling.
movie_title: The Virgin Psychics (Eiga: minna! Esupâ da yo!) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A melancholy drama that unfolds at a slow-burning pace, Midi Z's visually engrossing film is elevated by reserved yet indelible turns by Kai Ko and Wu Ke-xi.
Its narrative makes little sense, but the film is so entertaining audiences will overlook its ludicrous plotting and identify with the protagonists.
My Sassy Girl star Cha Tae-hyun plays an inadvertent Cupid in this fantasy melodrama, which merely treats its farfetched body-swapping premise as a convenient [narrative] device.
Featuring a cast of pop singers, 52Hz, I Love You proves to be a pleasant trifle, which does a far more effective job of pleasing the ear than stirring the heart.
While [the film] is never less than watchable, it's hard to shake the impression that Tsui [Hark] has partly ditched - or maybe failed to replicate - [Stephen] Chow's irreverent sense of humour.
movie_title: Journey to the West: The Demons Strike Back (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A relationship parable for the digital age, Perfect Strangers pits our deceitful natures against our dependence on smartphones, to mostly engaging effect.
This lushly coloured romantic fable is a bit like the pantomime cousin of Wong's 2046, in which a lovelorn Tony Leung also philosophises in frequent voice-over about the fate of those around him.
A thrilling but sometimes illogical piece of pulp entertainment that is crafted with impressive style.
movie_title: Death Note: Light Up the New World (Desu nôto: Light Up the New World) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [It] begins as an endearing comedy about the psychology of romance, before switching tone and morphing into a laborious will-she-won't-she melodrama with few surprises to offer.
Masahiro Motoki makes it all a joy to watch, lending a complex touch of humanity to an unlikeable role that's more involving than it has presumably any right to be.
Portman's conviction in the material oozes from this deeply poetic debut.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sword Master is easily one of the best Chinese-language remakes in recent times.

Its colourful characters, uninhibited display of gangland violence, and cheeky adaptation of political statements taken from the city's increasingly farcical reality are enough to make this an eloquent footnote in Hong Kong pop culture.
There's an alarming discrepancy between the Ringo Lam movies we love and the mediocre efforts that he's been producing since the Hong Kong film legend returned to directing.
A Kafkaesque tale about the Chinese bureaucracy's indifference to the people's legal rights.
This lurid and disorienting story of an old man out for revenge is a Memento-like narrative puzzle enhanced by the immense presence of Christopher Plummer.
A slow-burning drama on the paranoia and distrust inherent in human relationships.
One of the most poignant responses to a natural catastrophe that Japanese cinema has offered in the wake of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami.
The only bubble burst throughout this ode to luxury living? They wonder if Holly Golightly was really "a hooker".
One Night Only rarely bores - although it's also peppered with enough artificial plot turns and revelations to keep you from truly feeling for the protagonists.
You don't need a keen interest in history to be swept up in the deeply poignant delivery of Yoji Yamada's unmistakable anti-war message.

There are over 1.3 billion people in China -- soon to be the largest film market in the world -- so it's hard to understand why the Chinese producers of Heartfall Arises couldn't find one competent writer to produce a script.
Derek Tsang's film transcends its potentially cloying premise to tell a story of friendship and love that's at once melancholy and very emotional.
Put aside your longing for a conventional narrative, and Tran's exquisite tone poem could yet prove to be one of the most beautifully poignant films you'll come across in some time.
This TVB-presented Hong Kong-China co-production [is] a distinctly family-unfriendly movie scattered with bad language, psychotic characters and masturbation jokes.
A triple portrait of larger-than-life characters, who are all forced to renegotiate their brash and unruly criminal lifestyles in a dramatically changing political landscape.
A thoroughly engaging drama that is peppered with both improbably dark humour and pungent attempts at social commentary.
The clarity of the direction and the quality of the acting make it the best rendition of the author's work that any of us is likely to see either on screen or on stage.
I prophesied that Chaplin, with his finer comedy and his less spectacular farce, would not be able to hold his popularity against it. What has happened is precisely the reverse of what I predicted.
Buster Keaton is an able pantomimist; his morose and sensitive face commands a certain sympathy. We are, therefore, not absolutely unresponsive to his new comedy, Go West.

Lloyd has never been a very good actor; he has been a dummy for comic devices. And we are not much moved by the scene in The Freshman in which he learns at last that he has been the butt of his fellow students, instead of, as he has believed, their hero.
Though it includes some respectable elements, it is essentially a trashy moving picture based on a trashy story.
[A] curious and rather interesting production.
The film's bark is better than its bite.
The treatment shows a total lack of interest in character and motivation, not to mention utter disregard for most of the details that could render some plausibility to the story.
Despite being based on a critically acclaimed and successful novel, the film fails to produce either characters or events that can generate more than a passing interest.

Ozon's most controlled film to date has taken a claustrophobic character study... t and turned it into an often sardonic but always absorbing observation of human beings enslaved by their addiction to sex.
movie_title: Gouttes d'eau sur pierres brûlantes (Water Drops on Burning Rocks) (2000)

In many ways delivers an experience that's even better than the real thing.

movie_review_blurb: Sweet and heart-warming without being overly saccharine and smart without forcing one's brain to work too hard ... one of those rare feel-good comedies that actually makes you feel good.
A refreshing departure from the normal 'soldier's story' movies we've seen in recent years.
A ten hanky movie that ends up being just enough to make a nice noose for yourself after sitting through such an inexcusably downer ending.
Take one or two good ideas and add a lot of political thriller clichés and you end up with a disappointingly predictable action movie that doesn't necessarily deliver on the promised goods.
If nothing else, at least Lee can feel some degree of satisfaction knowing he's made a movie about as ineffective and incoherent as Clint Eastwood's Flag of our Fathers.
One can only assume that 'the blind leading the blind' best describes the decision to adapt this novel in such an abysmal manner.

A sweet story of young love on the streets of New York thrives on the chemistry between its two young stars, but is marred by the needlessly low-brow comedy added to try to create comedy that appeals to a larger (i.e. dumber) audience.

A fairly satisfying story of an underdog taking on the corporations that anyone can get behind, although it rarely feels like something so cinematic you might feel the need to rush to see it in theaters.
Ultimately, it's a satisfying character study, even if it ends much like far too many Romanian movies without a real conclusion or resolution.
A bit silly and predictable at times, but if you've been a long time fan of Tautou, you'll definitely want to see this.
An ambitious directorial debut from Irish actor Stuart Townsend that does an impressive job recreating the 1999 protests that accompanied the World Trade Organization's arrival in Seattle.
Another great departure for Smith to put his charm and popularity to the test, offering more than a few solid laughs within an original superhero premise.
This sweet inspirational story while familiar at times, keeps you thoroughly entertained by mixing healthy doses of humor into the real world drama.
Is to the country's troubled economy what An Inconvenient Truth was to global warming ... it's extremely effective at getting its message across.
This Hollywood-level suspense thriller never goes where you expect it to go, but often gets bogged down in over-exposition as the plot thickens... and thicken... and thickens...
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mediocre effort that never really goes anywhere and never really pays off, trying too hard to be funny without delivering on the premises introduced over the course of the movie.

Daring and uncompromisingly different from previous incarnations of Batman, Nolan hasn't redefined the superhero genre as much as created an unforgettable piece of crime fiction within the context of that realm.

Not just a vast improvement over its predecessor, but the quality on almost every level is almost night and day with a stronger story and some of the most mind-blowing creature and FX work we've seen this summer.
The presence of Cuba Gooding Jr. in this odd little indie comedy should set off early alarm bells.
Worthwhile for bringing these war games to light, but the filmmakers probably could have cut together their footage with narration and graphics to make it more interesting.

Maybe watching three older women prancing around in tight spandex singing ABBA is someone's idea of a good time, but I wouldn't want to be stuck in a room with those people for more than 90 minutes ever again.
Performed live, the haunting material finds new life ... Schnabel has created an incredibly artistic experience out of the concert with many moments that will give you goosebumps.
A fairly inconsistent effort assembled in a slipshod manner that doesn't do much to help one understand where this British gangster is coming from.
The influences for this poorly-made mock documentary are fairly obvious and if Lucas Akoskin was even 1/10th as funny as Sacha Baron Cohen, this movie might have worked.
If this movie doesn't make you laugh, you might want to give up on comedy altogether.
Could have been a lot worse, but should have been much better ... it's a movie you can watch once and be entertained, but it probably could never sustain multiple viewings like the best summer fare.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Exactly what you might expect, a mindless action flick that allows you to cheer as people get slaughtered while racing around in armored cars ... anyone expecting anything [else] is obviously in the wrong movie.
For those in the Red States anxiously awaiting a political comedy just for you, here comes an extremely erratic and disjointed attempt at mixing comedy with a message movie that fails on both counts.
Invariably, you may find yourself stopping to wonder whether what you just laughed at was actually funny, and that's a good way to kill any comedy right there.
A gorgeous looking film with a wry and clever script and a talented cast giving stellar performances, but one that suffers greatly from the painstakingly slow pace.
Not nearly as dramatic or visually captivating as last year's Control ... it does offer an interesting piece of the puzzle from the L.A. hardcore scene that hasn't been explored.
Since it's fairly obvious where things are going, it's somewhat of a waste of time when all's said and done ... unless you're REALLY into wine.

Probably could have cut out 15 to 20 minutes without losing anything, but if you're even remotely interested in this fascinating and enigmatic artist or the influence she's had on the world of rock, then you might want to check it out.
One of the most amazing cinematic experiences and achievements in terms of recreating a single event in history in the most comprehensive way.
It's the funniest movie of the year by far, one that can be watched repeatedly to gain more insight into its unmatched brilliance.

The movie is certainly flawed, but if you're able to suspend disbelief for the spiritual premise and can appreciate quiet little character-driven films where not much happens, you can do worse than this innocent and often lovely film.

May be a better-than-average Saturday morning cartoon, but as a theatrical feature, it has limited appeal to young kids and the few diehard fans who'll be able to overlook some of the silliness inherent in the story.
Another intriguing take on affairs of the heart from the master of the artform with some solid performances, most notably from Javier Bardem and Rebecca Hall.
A great cast, solid writing, some poppy head-bopping tunes and a story full of warmth and laughs often makes up for its sometimes predictable high concept plot.
You might leave the theatre wondering whose minds were more twisted and demented, those who wrote this movie, or your own?
Sweet, sentimental and funny in a warm and fuzzy way, even if it's somewhat predictable and few of the actors seem very Jewish.
Might never be viewed as light entertainment, but the strong performances and ideas make it a satisfying film, one that you can ponder and discuss, as well as a powerful tribute to our troops.
An endearing kids' adventure like the kind of movies Disney used to make in the '70s and Amblin made in the '80s.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy that's surprisingly low on genuine laughs ... a trite, tamed and toned-down version of Apatow's high school formula with little of the pop or pizzazz of his other recent movies.
Anyone who's ever been a fan of the Clash or Strummer's music should be fascinated by this comprehensive look at his eccentric life.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The only thing that saves it from being a Lifetime movie is Cusack's ever-present charm and personality.
Takes a more direct approach to its politics but should have gone just a bit further if it really wanted to leave any sort of lasting impression.
An interesting though sometimes infuriating exercise from the veteran director that (as usual) goes just that little bit too far.
Hopeless romantics shouldn't have problems forgiving some of the foibles and faux pas made in the telling of the story.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkably faithful adaptation of King's novella ... destined to be considered among the classic King horror adaptations.
Doesn't take long for the movie to reveal itself as an extremely contrived and predictable movie that tries too hard to tug on the heartstrings.
Another tragically banal step backwards in black filmmaking that looks to keep it from ever being taken seriously.
Frank Langella and Lili Taylor give great performances in what is essentially another painfully slow and bland digitally-shot indie drama.
A masterpiece of music, words and images that should get even the staunchest Dylan-haters interested in learning more about the man.
With better actors in the two main roles, this movie would probably have been great, but with Christensen and Alba, it's just okay.
Combining the poor choice of Will Smith in the lead with some of the worst CG work since Van Helsing, this dog makes the recent The Invasion come across like a masterpiece.
Frankly, there's a way to get a message across and this sort of talking heads doc by numbers isn't it.

This masterpiece of production design and world-building might take some time to get into, but once past the confusing premise, it's worthy of plunking down another $7 to 12 to find out what happens next.
A genuinely touching crowd-pleaser and a real treat.
It's not quite clear why Venditti thought the film's annoying teen with ADD would make an interesting subject.
Brings Khaled Hosseini's epic vision to gorgeous life [and] leaves an equally lasting impression on viewers as the novel did with readers.
An extreme departure for P.T. Anderson, this violent and jarring oil epic is an achievement in cinematic storytelling that's hard to ignore.
Most people seeing this movie might wonder what Queen Latifah did to convince Terrence Howard to take on what will surely be his worst role of the year.
This grisly, grim and ghoulish gothic tale of vengeance is a thoroughly entertaining gore-filled experience, whether you're a fan of musicals or not.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even fans of the romantic comedy genre might have trouble suspending disbelief for this ridiculous bit of fluff that rarely knows whether it wants to be a serious drama about grieving or a light comedy about finding love.
The genius of Jake Kasdan's fourth and best film lies in the fact that it starts out as a very faithful spoof of Walk the Line but then slowly evolves into something much cooler.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unquestionably one of the most amazing films dealing with man's battle against nature since Kevin Macdonald's Touching the Void
This too-cool-for-school Singles wannabe could have been great, but it never really goes anywhere due to its poor execution
It pulls you into Burton's world with its stunning performances and visuals.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Never tries to go too far below the surface, instead taking a snide and cynical approach to the meet-cute romantic comedy, filling it with all of the most obvious clichés and stereotypes in its desperate attempt for yucks.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A well-crafted directorial debut that does a worthy job getting one thinking about those who have been the most affected by the war.
Ultimately, the film does work as an inspirational tale even if it requires way too much effort and patience on the viewer's part before it gets there.
Seinfeld has completely dumbed-down his normal clever wit in order to appeal to younger kids; they're probably the only ones who might enjoy this.
Like a quirky poor man's version of The World According to Garp or Forrest Gump, it's hard to believe that it's actually based on the true story of a real person.
A tragically atrocious roadblock in the momentum Baumbach established with his previous movie, neither recapturing any of that magic nor paving any new ground.
Fessenden's best film and a huge turning point for him as a filmmaker, promising even stronger work to come.
Half of me hoped it would end with someone saying, 'Maybe we shouldn't form a Jane Austen Book Club after all' ... That would have been a much better happy ending.
Way too long and could have easily been trimmed by a good half hour, but it turns a new corner in [Sean Penn's] career as a filmmaker
Not nearly as dumb as the previous movie, but still fairly dull despite a few impressive action sequences.
Somewhat funny, but in strange and subtle ways, even by Anderson's standards.
Takes forever to get anywhere and the ridiculous ending doesn't make it worth the journey.
So sickeningly adorable and sweet that you'll be barfing sugarcubes long before the halfway point. The fact that they can stretch this idea into a movie longer than 90 minutes boggles the mind.
A fairly conservative and mundane character drama that doesn't offer any true proof of the joy and wonders of love promised by the title.
The open-endedness of the film makes for a rather unsatisfying non-conclusion to the story ... but like the best documentaries, it leaves you asking questions without trying to answer them for you.
A pleasant surprise with a high concept premise that allows for funnier situations and characters than some of Christopher Guest's last few offerings.
If you've ever been a fan of Cobain's music and want to learn what made him tick, this film is an amazing experience that's not to be missed.
An utterly charming crowd-pleasing comedy that adds another impressive performance to Steve Carell's resume.
The material is often too bizarre and esoteric for ordinary people to be able to relate to any of it.
While obviously important to those who made the film, [it] probably won't hold that much interest to anyone not directly involved with the story.
An entertaining, masterfully-crafted crime flick even if it isn't altogether original or groundbreaking compared to Ridley Scott's classic films.
An old school character-driven police drama that comes from the heart of a filmmaker who's clearly in complete sync with his cast and crew.
Commendable for its daring, unconventional vision of vampires, but its erratic pacing makes it a jarring experience that's hard to adjust to.
This riveting thriller may prove to be one of the most surprising debuts in a lucrative new filmmaking career for Ben Affleck.
To say that this low-fi indie movie is strange would be doing a disservice to quirky movies that thrive on their strangeness, rather than just being strange for the sake of spicing things up.
An emotionally-draining yet uplifting film about grief and redemption that should put Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier on America's radar.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Conventional in its storytelling and far less effective for the effort, but [Ruffalo's] performance often overshadows his Oscar-nominated castmates.
Anyone interested in politics and the conflict in the Mid-East should be able to enjoy this fascinating and informative portrait of a former president.
Doesn't seem to have very much plot or purpose, besides being an overly sweet and cute love letter to New York City, but the writing and storytelling just aren't there.
An amazing man and an amazing film.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Marc Levin's biggest coup was actually finding Barnes and having him tell his story in his own words, which is ultimately the most interesting part of the movie
While this '70s comedy remake isn't a complete return to form for Peter and Bobby Farrelly, it's certainly a step back in the right direction for the pioneers of raunch.
Entertaining fun [but] flawed in its overuse of Hollywood cliches and trickery that makes it predictable and less believable.
Satrapi is an interesting woman who clearly has a distinctive way of telling her story, which is what makes this film such a uniquely joyous experience.
Falls quite short of its mark, mostly due to the poor casting as well as a deathly slow pace that far too often veers away from [the film's] greatest strength, which is the music.
If Brooks' attempts to replicate the magic of About a Boy weren't obvious by the end credits, the Badly Drawn Boy song will drive the point home.
[The] combination of creature effects, action and believable situations is what ultimately puts the movie on par with the first couple 'Harry Potter' movies.
Michel Joelsas, the young actor who carries the film, is quite a find ... a fun and charming film.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An impressive feat as a vehicle for Doug Liman to pull out the stops with some of the most jaw-dropping stunts shot in some of the most amazing locations on earth.
Not as quirky as Gondry's previous movies but not quite mainstream either. [It] has enough heart in the end to make up for the fact that it isn't nearly as funny as its premise might suggest.
Mainly interesting for its premise and noteworthy for the main performance. [Not] nearly as deserving of accolades as many of the foreign language films that were ignored by the Academy.
This reprehensible effort is not only an embarrassment to Duke, but to everyone involved ... the offensively homophobic message behind this movie is not the only thing that makes it truly awful.
This isn't the definitive post-apocalyptic gore-fest some might hope for, and is more memorable for its cast of talented Atlanta-based actors ... than the talent of the three filmmakers.
A competently-made action-thriller but nothing particularly ground-breaking once it casually discards its pretense of being told from multiple points of view.
Semi-Pro joins Anchorman and Elf as one of Ferrell's funnier efforts.
A tragic waste of time and talent in every sense of the word.
In the hands of a more competent director, Peter Morgan's strong script might have been turned into something more memorable.
Vaughn's ambitious dream project offers more than just a look at four budding stand-up comics, but a look at our country from a very unique perspective as well.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: However one can fault the execution, there's something ironic about its sweet message about accepting one's own faults.
On par with Little Children in terms of the writing and performances, including one of Kate Beckinsale's shining moments.
Kids will probably appreciate it more than their parents, but those with a twisted sense of humor should get a few laughs out of Chow's oddest film yet.
All over the place in tone, never knowing if it wants to be a relationship comedy, a serious drama or a Hitchcock murder thriller.
If this film really epitomizes the way that teens talk and act ... then I seriously fear for the future of this country.
Owes more to Eastenders than The Italian Job with its mostly implausible piece of fiction disguising itself as a true crime story.
Cleverly written and brilliantly made ... the type of classy and tasteful British crime-drama that Caine has long been associated with.
An atrocious waste of a perfectly good CGI budget ... at least the Geico commercials make an effort to get the historical accuracy right
As much as Never Back Down tries to be The Fist and the Furious, it's really just a load of Raging Bullsh*t.
An amazing look back at a time in history when many people weren't alive, and it's a commendable and often impressive effort all around.
You can't help but be impressed by how many great bands played through [the club] before it shut its doors, just days before 9/11.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This look at the Mexican immigrant experience offers a few new ideas to the currently hot topic , but it's hard not to feel like we've seen this sort of story too many times in recent years.
A mostly dull and nonsensical attempt at a revenge thriller that trips and falls flat on its face far too many times to stand up to some of [Assayas'] stronger work.
A brilliant piece of filmmaking in the way it contrasts the beauty of Rio de Janeiro with the violence that affects the lives of the teens living in the city's favelas.
A sporadically enjoyable no-brainer dramedy with a very simple premise that allows Nicholson or Freeman to coast through it without having to do much heavy hitting.
It's hard to fault the filmmakers, because given the premise, it could have been much MUCH worse.
This has nothing to offer that we haven't seen before, making it one of those winter offerings that will be long forgotten by the summer.
An uninventive, unexciting and ultimately ineffective follow-up ... We can only hope that the sub-title means that this moneymaking farce is finally over.
Only slightly better than Chapter 27, it's questionable whether even the most morbidly curious John Lennon fan might have any interest in sitting through nearly two hours of this creepy lunatic.
With so much pointless violence for the sake of violence and a terrible non-sensical ending, this film is a grueling and pointless exercise that never fully delivers on its premise.
Doesn't pretend to be something more than a fun movie for women, as it offers a lighter look at romance and relationships without ever getting preachy or anti-male.
Hopefully, Allen has finally gotten the UK out of his system with his latest substandard film.
If you haven't already questioned the current government administration about some of their actions and tactics than this movie should be the last nail in that coffin.
Somewhat surprising that it's not nearly as awful as it could have been, but tragic to watch Diane Keaton's career continue its path into embarrassing roles that undermine her acting talent.
Worthwhile only for the scale of the destruction and the sheer audacity of its marketing campaign.
Sadly, it's a classic example of why some novels just don't translate well when adapted to the screen.
This entertaining and often moving documentary should help even the youngest of viewer get in touch with their own mortality and make it clear that life doesn't have to end at 60.
If In Bruges doesn't end up being the funniest and most quotable movies of the year, then it should be very close.
Whenever you may think you know where things are going, Anderson throws a number of clever and unexpected twists that keeps you on your toes.
Jenkins' overly clever and stylish but ultimately shoddy and boring debut is mostly an awful waste of time.
A great script and one of the more innovative indie comedies in recent memory.
Aside from a few amusing scenes, it mostly comes across as a dry exercise, and the ending is so grim that much of the earlier charm might be forgotten.
Brett Simon's clever high school noir debut is more Heathers than John Hughes
movie_title: Assassination of a High School President (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully refreshing and original film; this may be John Malkovich's best role and performance, maybe of his career.
The worthwhile attempts at creating realistic character dynamics and situations within a very specific era in New York is notable for sure.
A blatantly derivative serial killer thriller that proceeds to tick off every single cliché of the genre ... has nothing to offer beyond what we've already seen before.

Might be hard for those not conditioned to the generally cynical tone of Palahniuk's work to get very far, although it's much easier to swallow (no pun intended) due to the winning performances from Rockwell and Huston.
Those looking for an innovative new take on the prison genre should be pleased with the latest from this talented filmmaker.

The unique use of character dynamics combined with Blackburn's keen visual sense makes it a thinking person's horror flick that surpasses its genre by introducing a viable new cinematic voice and vision.
Unquestionably one of the worst movies Maria Bello has ever done ... this isn't just bad, but 'Tideland bad.'
[A] generally charming, funny and sweet movie that's far more accessible than past efforts [from the Duplass Brothers].
Someone else should have seen the obvious hurdle of making a horror movie that relies solely on Jessica Alba's acting abilities.
If you're a fan of watching poker on television and inventive comedy than The Grand is an entertaining experience that delivers on its premise.
Has enough funny moments and original ideas that it's genuinely enjoyable based on the strength of its script and cast alone.
Strange but wonderful ... up there with some of Leigh's best movies, driven by riveting performances from Sally Hawkins and Eddie Marsan.
If Phoenix's transition from actor to rapper turns out to be true, this would make quite an intriguing swan song for sure.
As disturbing as it is compelling, Ridley Scott has outdone himself with his first modern-day political thriller, delivering his strongest movie since Black Hawk Down.
A fairly standard and straight-forward biopic, but Sheen just has a way of personifying these public figures [and it's] another role perfectly suited for him.
A head-turning performance by Clive Owen and a similar breakthrough from Emma Booth ... an incredibly powerful and moving film.
Fits perfectly next to Gilliam's earlier films, and more often than not, his distinctive humor and the visuals help the movie overcome any of the weaker moments.
An impressive character piece that explores important themes ... as well as embellishing aspects of the original story that have never been fleshed out so elaborately.
Really pulls you in and sticks with you ... an incredibly strong piece of dramatic storytelling.

Michael Moore fans should be able to appreciate what he does with this serious subject matter, while still keeping the movie entertaining and funny.
Surely Isaac Asimov, Philip K. Dick and Stan Winston must be tossing in their grave for what all their creative and innovative ideas have wrought.
A refreshing new spin on the zombie flick, one with humor and heart, but also a great introduction to an innovative and talented new filmmaker.

Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange is an easy in for those looking for comparisons in terms of tone and mood and style.
An okay film with a funny premise that offers enough laughs to excuse the weaker direction.
The Yes Men Fix the World definitely shows they're one step closer to achieving their goal.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Few people who walk out of this movie will be able to forget Carey Mulligan's Jenny ... finds many layers in the way it explores the world at that time.
Jonze has produced a gorgeous $80 million Muppet Movie in the shape of an art film that will bore kids as much as it will depress adults.
Strong performances by Gerard Butler and Jamie Foxx drive this smart, sharp thriller that will keep you guessing with shocks and surprises at every turn.

A futuristic take on "Pinocchio"... a competently-made animated adventure that probably will wow kids more than it will keep adults entertained for more than a few minutes.
It's fairly obvious Paul Weitz is trying to mimic the style of Tim Burton ... it's hard not to immediately fault the movie for failing to achieve the same impeccable blend of dark humor and wonder.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not nearly as painful to get through as the Weinsteins' bastardization of Tom Yum Goong but those looking for more of the innovative modern-day action that made the original Ong Bak such a breath of fresh air in a somewhat tired genre might
By no means the perfect biopic, but one that covers a lot of ground in telling Amelia Earhart's story. The amount of research that went into (it) is fairly impressive.

movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A fine example of how a talented filmmaker can tackle a horror sub-genre in a way that's stylistically reverential but also original in its own way.
An abysmal waste of time and talent, a movie that takes a weak premise that could barely sustain a short homemade movie.
Consistently an entertaining and fascinating film that lifts the veil of secrecy to help us get closer to Jackson in ways that may have never been possible if he was still with us.

An amusing film (albeit in spurts)... (although) Armando Iannucci's In the Loop is a hard act to follow for any politically-tinged comedy.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Who knows what Von Trier was trying to achieve with the movie--some sort of catharsis, possibly?--but it's doubtful anyone will want to sit through it a second time to figure it out.

Some of the finest comedy dialogue you'll hear this year, as Iannucci and his team have created sharp, snarky insults and comebacks.

movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Too long, too bland and never really pays off in the way one might hope with such a strong premise and cast.

The type of glorious filmmaking and storytelling that should appeal to everyone ... a wonderful and magical film that should be seen and enjoyed as a family.
The sickest and most disturbing movie you'll see this year, extremely effective on every level without cowtowing to the overused formulas that have become standard in modern horror.

The most creative, timely and relevant doc of the year.

Dumb, boring and predictable, rarely ever exceeding its TV movie esthetic and leading to the most ridiculous last-minute twist.
For someone claiming to be 'No Impact Man,' Beavan's efforts at reaching this lofty goal does in fact leave a very big impact on the viewer.
This historical film has to be seen for the glorious way it takes you back through time, making you feel as if you are part of Disney's entourage.
Shows the very growth and evolution that proves [Reitman] is a filmmaker who will be with us, making quality films that leave us deeply moved, for a very long time.
