An incredibly moving experience to watch the struggles everyone went through, all framed by the protest songs of the time and what they represented to those in the trenches.

While it's hard to give the movie a whole-hearted recommendation, Legion is better than it should have been due to Stewart's attempts to NOT make it into just another high concept video game existing merely to set up a franchise.
Such an inventive and quirky film, it's hard to ignore what a distinctive voice Rhodes brings to indie comedy. Casting Buscemi in this role couldn't be more perfect.
A documentary that is at times reminiscent of Man on Wire and The Fog of War both in tone and filmmaking prowess.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A top-notch thriller ... a well-crafted addition to a genre that has made a refreshing and welcome comeback in recent years.
Frozen is horrifying and brutal at times but without ever losing sight of important things like creating characters you really care about whether they live or die.
A terrific and well-realized first film, one that allows you into a world that very few outsiders have a chance to see and allows you to marvel at the storytelling skills of these two filmmakers.
A strong crime-thriller on par with some of the films from the Coen Brothers, one that keeps you captivated with every twist and development.
What might have been a fairly standard buddy comedy is elevated by a hilariously irreverent performance by Travolta and Morel's knack for creating exciting action pieces.
A fascinating film, but for every interesting idea explored, there are just as many that don't seem to have as much relevance; the film is never focused enough to be wholly effective.
Like a cross between The Road Warrior and "Deadwood" ... a generic post-Apocalypse movie with a few cool action scenes and a mostly ridiculous premise.
Who knows how many people know who Aebi is or about his selfless efforts, but it's inspiring to watch and Martina Egl has done a good job finding an inventively artistic way of telling his story.
Any potential for depth or intelligence has been sucked out by the very holiday the film attempts to glorify. The two hours watching this movie was no fairy tale.
Audiard has created another masterpiece, almost like his 'Godfather' trilogy if it were done over the course of one movie.
A fascinating indictment of how legislation and politics can be abused in a way that quite literally misses the bigger picture.
People who enjoy high fantasy like Carroll's classic work are more than happy to experience the insanity, but don't necessarily want to be driven insane themselves.
Brooklyn's Finest is a movie that could easily have gone horribly wrong if handled differently, but Antoine Fuqua is clearly a filmmaker at the top of his game.
Director Bong continues to be on par with Park Chan-wook, Kim Ki-Duk and other (Korean filmmakers) in terms of pushing the envelope in what can be done with storytelling on film.
If you have any interest whatsoever in writing a screenplay or trying to get a gig writing in Hollywood, this is a must-see film and a great companion to the book.
Its attempt at introducing 'Bourne'-style action into a real war setting is always on the precipice of utterly failing as a concept.
Has a lot of spirit and heart and actually quite sweet, but it tries to shoehorn too many ideas into one movie and not all of them work.
Misguided and embarrassing for all those involved; could have easily been a segment in the atrocious Valentine's Day
There are enough layers to the drama in Remember Me that makes it hard to immediately discount or dismiss it as frivolous teen girl fare.
A truly warm and wonderful film that work by using simpler storytelling to explore very deep human emotions.
Feels like a filmmaker more concerned with making this grand-looking epic and less concerned with keeping modern horror lovers as riveted to the screen as the original did back in its day.
As hard as the subject of incest and rape and abuse can be, it's a truly inspirational tale of overcoming the odds and never losing sight of your dreams.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Plummer is just fantastic overall, and easily the best reason to sit through the film's two-hour running time.
Predictable as hell but delivering exactly what's advertised ... the rapport between Adams and Goode is often enough to keep this movie from totally sinking into its own formula-driven plot.

A grim but gripping film that foresees doom and gloom, not just for the economy but for the entire country as a whole; one can decide for themselves whether or not [Michael Ruppert's] claims are valid.
Anderson's first foray into animation is far from fantastic ... his attempt to stay true to his gut while maintaining the integrity of Dahl's storytelling is a losing battle.
Particularly effective in showcasing the good Kunstler did for so many people and that tends to overpower all the bad stuff for which the majority probably remember Kunstler for later in his life.

All the outright silliness can be quite entertaining, but it's unsatisfying to watch a movie spend so much time developing characters you can't possibly care about as you wait for Emmerich to throw in the next wave of destruction.
Perfectly harmless fun ... the unwieldy number of characters keeps it from ever being something more than a movie for 40-something women looking to relive their teeny bopper years.
A fine bookend to Katheryn Bigelow's The Hurt Locker, showing another side of how the war at home can be just as rigorous as the one abroad.
Hard not to be impressed by the spectacular way Woo gives Western audiences an Asian history lesson that's thoroughly entertaining at the same time.
George Clooney is amazing in this even though he wasn't even born at the time it was made!
Alternates between grueling amounts of bad dialogue and silly humor for the teen set; except for a few moments involving the werewolves and the Volturi, it's fairly dismissible drivel.
An action film that only works as long as there are ninjas on-screen slicing and dicing each other, and not so much when anyone opens their mouth and speaks.
An all-around warm and entertaining film ... has a romanticism that we haven't seen very much from Linklater in recent years.
Maguire delivers a dynamic performance unlike anything else we've seen from him...the movie might have been overwrought with grief in the hands of another director.
Confirms beyond a shadow of a doubt that Andrea Arnold's previous film Red Road was no fluke.
Has many sweet moments, but tends to veer into territory that's overly sentimental and saccharine.
A beautiful-looking film, very poignant and moving, showing Ford to be a real filmmaker and not some flash in the pan trying his hand at a new medium.
Michael Clarke Duncan steals every single scene ... a very different role for the actor played so over-the-top that you can't help but be impressed and amazed.
Jeff Bridges realizing one of his most memorable film characters in years with a performance you won't quickly forget.
Can easily sit on anyone's DVD/Blu-ray shelf alongside Aliens and The Abyss further bolstering Cameron's already impressive film legacy.
Always fully aware it need not involve big words or ideas to offer light entertaining fare even if there's only so far you can take such a predictable premise.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When a movie with such a high pedigree feels so uninspired, you have to wonder whether there's any hope whatsoever for the romantic comedy genre.
Masterfully crafted by Guy Ritchie, this refreshing take on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's sleuth is a great vehicle for Downey to create another distinctively eccentric character.
This quirky dark comedy offers you 90 minutes of [Michael Cera] not just doing what he does best but also showing that he has a few new tricks up his sleeve.
That rare art form of documentary verité, Castain-Taylor's camera acts as a silent observer showing the rigorous trip these men have taken for many years.
An enjoyable look into one man's emotional journey even if it doesn't offer anything that new or indispensable in the grand scheme of things.
In any other world, this would be getting a DVD or Syfy-only release, and Jacobson's talents would be better utilized directing Playboy Channel interstitials.
Successfully shows another side of society that feels foreign and unfamiliar at first, but one that's infinitely more interesting when put into context of our own lives.
A strong high concept heist thriller, sometimes hindered by the predictability of the genre and it's marketing but regularly salvaged by the movie's strong direction and the quality of the cast.
If nothing else, it's two hours of fun, unadulterated entertainment like the kind only Guy Ritchie can deliver ... requires a small amount of patience before its second half pay-off.
Hits every emotional nail in the head so perfectly ... you'll not be able to walk away from this movie at least not somewhat more enlightened than when you walked in.
It's hard not to feel like this is little more than an interim piece in the overall story, presumably leading to something much bigger next time around.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A disjointed attempt at covering far too many angles and artists to make for a cohesive film ... this isn't the movie that'll get these musicians the respect they deserve.
Ron Howard has taken a great play and made it even better, perfectly preserving the performances by Langella and Sheen that made Peter Morgan's work so special.
Bad writing, worse acting and violence that redefines the word 'excessive' makes it clear that The Punisher is one Marvel character that probably should stay in the comic books.
One could have made a much stronger movie with a cast this good, one that wasn't so erratic and driven by such obvious and formulaic holiday silliness.
Anything good that can be said about this movie tends to be hindered by the ugly animation, which pales in comparison to anything else being done in the field right now.
Williams is fascinating to watch on screen ... but a strong performance does not necessarily an entertaining movie make, and there seems to be little point or purpose to this.
There's a realism to this story we don't often see in crime dramas, and that can only have come from someone who actually lived through it themselves.
Despite the generally weak acting, this modern remake is as effective and thoughtful at capturing the global zeitgeist and how the world today might react to an alien invasion as the original.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A generally enjoyable but problematic departure for Eastwood which works best during its lighter moments but gets too dark while trying to create heightened tension and drama.
Another dog of a comedy, lame even in comparison to what Carrey's done in the past, and its tiresome premise doesn't do much to help the matter.
The results look nice, but there's little way to get past its intriguing but impenetrable (and unmarketable) premise.
Just another innocuous character dramedy that might have been handled better if done independently.
Gus Van Sant's return to mainstream filmmaking [is] one of the more fascinating political biopics in recent memory.
A wonderfully romantic movie that you don't have to be in your 40's or older to appreciate and enjoy.
Who on earth seriously wants to watch an entire movie of Kate and Leo squabbling as their marriage implodes?
Riveting and unforgettable, this intense drama really pulls you in and holds you with a terrific script and four unforgettable Oscar-worthy performances.
Marred by hammy overacting and horrendous writing by a filmmaker who clearly doesn't share Eisner's charming sense of humor.
Just one long ridiculous string of moviemaking cliches that prevents the film from having any of the desired impact.
You're likely to leave this movie wondering what you've just watched, as if you've been abused worse than the poor kidnapped girl.
There's great potential to be a classic Vegas indie drama ala Swingers or The Cooler though it's only 60% its way to getting there.
Any intelligence gets lost in an unsatisfying ending that doesn't justify the brain cells lost while getting there.
The amazing visuals and sound design (make) the movie so riveting, but its ability to let Rockwell shine with such a brilliant and rounded performance will probably be appreciated more.
Shows Jenkins to be an innovative and original voice to indie filmmaking, one certainly worth watching if he can deliver a second effort as enjoyable as this debut.
The charm of Manchevski's film clearly lies in its ability to embrace its eccentricities and pull together a number of disparate ideas into what's generally a satisfying thriller.
One of those rare examples of a high concept thriller where the elements come together in a way that delivers something far more original and appealing than one might imagine.
Too derivative and laden with plot twists to be effective, it's hard to enjoy this cluttered remake knowing how much better the original movie is.
Meryl Streep is absolutely the least interesting thing about this inventive doc that takes an unprecedented look at the staging of a high-profile theater production.
Nothing more than an attempt to stroke the "Star Wars" fans ... they're probably the only ones who might appreciate what is generally a weak and unfunny movie.
The epic scope of the filmmaking gives you newfound appreciation for what a visionary filmmaker can achieve when given the chance to make films without compromise.
There are far worse ways of kicking yourself into the holiday spirit than this inventive variation on the Meet the Parents formula.

Even without reading the book, one can easily deduce how this adaptation will explore every single manipulative trick in the book to tug at the heartstrings of women whose emotions are easily manipulated.

As relaxing as it may be to watch the Morning Light floating idly at sea with glorious sunsets setting behind it, it doesn't make for a particularly entertaining movie and it's certainly not something that will inspire anyone to get into sailing as a spor
Excellent performances by Brolin, Cromwell and others get lost within a generally dull piece of political fantasy fiction trying to sell itself as an entertaining biopic.
As raunchy as you'd expect from an R-rated teen sex comedy, but surprisingly clever and even sweet at times.
An embarrassment to a genre that's already delivered some of the worst movies of the last ten years.
A simply-made yet entertaining doc that has a similar appeal as Alexander Payne's Election while following in the vein of docs like American Teen and Spellbound.
Most of it seems like pointless goofing around, offering lots of filth and very little semblance of wisdom.
Suffers from its lack of focus by trying to create an overly complex story that would probably have been just as interesting if it were kept simpler ... and shorter.
As hard as it must have been to screw up a Joe Carnahan script, the fact that Gavin O'Connor is no Martin Scorsese or Michael Mann is blatantly obvious from this weak effort.
One of the most intriguing character studies in recent memory; a dialogue heavy drama that never gets dull and will leave you drained from the amount of emotions explored.
The thoughts and emotions the movie stirs up in the viewer makes it one of the more powerful documentaries of the year.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A lot of thought may have gone into constructing this intricate, remotely clever, but ultimately dour and depressing, directorial debut from Charlie Kaufman, but it probably wasn't worth the effort.
[It] could never be deemed a 'good movie' but it's one of those bad movies so entertaining and fun it's hard to fully condemn it.

If you liked the previous four movies, there's little reason why you won't find at least a few things to enjoy in this one, but it's definitely getting to the point where it's dubious whether they can keep it going much longer...
One of the more comprehensive looks at bullfighting we've seen in this country.
The better than usual cast offers enough new twists to keep it from being just another Kevin Smith comedy.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Is this the funniest movie from Wain or anyone involved in the cast? No, probably not, but you should get enough laughs out of it that it shouldn't be completely written off as a loss.
If Jackson and the late Bernie Mac weren't chewing up the scenery in an incessant game of one-upmanship, this might have worked nearly as well (as The Blues Brothers).
Not quite on par with Life is Beautiful or Schindler's List but it's still a powerful film, and a more than worthy addition to the genre due to its unique perspective.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly in the future, depicted here so stylishly, Andrew Lloyd Webber is probably turning in his grave.
Daniel Craig has firmly ensconced himself as one of the definitive Bonds, one now fully updated for the 21st Century.
Clearly one of the best movies of the year, Slumdog Millionaire is a fine example of why we love to watch movies.
Essentially a vanity project, a budget Ocean's 11 for Davi and his pals to sing some doo-wop tunes and ham it up.

Those looking for a cheery family gathering for the holidays flick might want to look elsewhere. Those who enjoy quirky family dramas, beautifully written, performed and shot will be thrilled by Desplechin's latest.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's strongest CG animated effort to date can be credited to the strength of a premise that mixes what's worked so well in earlier Disney animated films with a better awareness of what makes a movie entertaining both for kids and adults.
Essentially, a CW take on Anne Rice, catering to the gooey-eyed fans of Meyer's novels and their unrealistic romantic expectations.
One of the most powerful and moving films this year, a personal film that perfectly captures the feelings of anger and loss that accompany a loved one's untimely death.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly a new low for the genre as well as a career low for Columbus.
You can do far worse than this when it comes to a date movie, but knowing so much about how the opposite sex thinks will surely put a quick and sour end to date night.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Completely misses the point of what worked ... a relatively unsatisfying rehash of what's come before while barely moving the franchise past the overused cliches.
There's a true filmmaking force at work here; open-minded film enthusiasts should appreciate [Johnson's] charming and unique approach to the heist comedy
Fails because it doesn't really get you excited about the return of the franchise... and a lot of that comes down to the cheesy writing and bad acting.
An interesting character-based experiment by Soderbergh, one that's more fully-realized than some of his other recent ideas.
It never quite finds its comic footing, but kids will probably love it--they might even learn a thing or two.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Grueling, but mostly watchable. Funny? Not so much.
Better than at least 90% of the non-Pixar animated movies being produced, as well as a film experience that can be fully embraced for its originality of vision and tone.
This is truly masterful and glorious filmmaking that's guaranteed a spot in my Top 10 of the year.
Such a heartfelt inspirational story that one can fully understand why it seemed like such a worthwhile effort to capture the results of Stephenson's efforts on film.
Drag Me to Hell more than lives up to the hype surrounding the horror master's return to the genre.
Sometimes gets bogged down in its own weirdness, but a genuinely unique piece of horror filmmaking.
Todd Phillips masterfully shows that the combination of unexpected ingredients can create a potent chemistry that elevates a simple premise.
An amusing and incredibly strange experience that might have you laughing at the ballsiness of pulling something as crazy as this off.
Remaining faithful to stronger source material makes Ron Howard and Tom Hanks' second Dan Brown adaptation a far superior effort in every possible way.
May not be as exciting as some may hope for what is essentially a summer popcorn flick. What keeps it from being a complete loss is the strong character work from Washington and Gandolfini.
Simple and effective with a quirky charm that's infectious due to the perfect pairing of Krasinski and Rudolph and the decidedly different approach Mendes has taken with the material.
Who knows why anyone thought a kid's movie about financial investing might be of interest to anyone of any age? Effortlessly hammers another nail into Eddie Murphy's credibility as a comic star.
A wonderful character study not only about the four main characters but also New York City itself and how it affects everyone who enters it.
Being directed by Michael Bay, you will probably go in expecting a lot of action and explosions ... but this is clearly the Bay of Pearl Harbor and Armageddon
A brilliantly realized character-driven thriller likely to leave a lasting impression and make you completely forget everything you thought you knew about the day-to-day lives of soldiers in Iraq.
Like an amalgam of every "ABC After-School Special" ever made ... makes most Lifetime Channel movies seem competent by comparison.

As technically flawless a film as we've come to expect from a master filmmaker like Michael Mann, but handled far more clinically than some might expect considering the subject matter and the summer release.

There's little question that the movie will most be remembered for its introduction of the luscious Louise Bourgouin. Fontaine has a way at bringing out her oozing sex appeal without the movie ever feeling exploitative.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even more insane and hysterical than Borat, Sacha Baron Cohen's hilarious follow-up is also far more coherent and effective at using shock factor to get you laughing.
Seems destined to join classic concert films like Woodstock and Gimme Shelter in the musical archives for its ability to capture the feel of the times and really make you feel like you were there.
You have to give Lynn Shelton a lot of credit for trying to explore a part of the male lifestyle that often deliberately goes unspoken.
Shows a new level of filmmaking incompetence previously only seen in the films of Dr. Uwe Boll. It is just plain awful
An important film, a fascinating and intelligent doc that's easily one of the best of the year. Could very well make a huge difference in how you decide what you put in your mouth.
Push barely measures up to even the worst moments on "Heroes," and it makes 20th Century Fox's weaker superhero efforts look much better.
One of the more unique romantic comedies since Garden State, one that's sweet and strange at the same time.
Will be remembered for the unforgettable performance by Swinton that drives this inventive thriller.
Smart, tense and effective ... an intelligent conspiracy thriller that takes its time setting things up, but delivers one of the most impressive set pieces of the year.
As hard as this movie tries to 'bring it on', it probably should have left the cheerleading realm well enough alone ... one of the most blatantly sexist and homophobic comedies in some time.
Wajda has assembled a really amazing ensemble cast to realize an excellent script ... beautifully shot by Pawel Edelman with some truly gorgeous sequences.
The process for putting on a high-profile fashion show seems endlessly fascinating even if it's hard to find reason to care about Jay McCarroll as the film's central subject.
This politically-minded ensemble drama's obvious attempts at being Traffic or Crash barely gets out of the garage before it stalls in neutral.
Zack Snyder's attempt at being faithful to Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons' vision is ultimately the film's biggest fault since it makes the flaws in the original source material far more obvious.
Unlike most movies that deal with women's issues, this is one that can be enjoyed equally by guys rather than being so fueled by estrogen that it's unbearable.
Neither a conventional spy flick nor a traditional romantic comedy, Duplicity is a satisfying mix of the two that's as entertaining as it is thought-provoking
One of the few touchy-feely relationship comedies that will probably play as well or better with guys than it does with women.
Cute and clever and often entertaining, but never quite lives up to the potential of the premise nor is it as funny as you might hope based on the talent involved.
Anyone with half a brain is likely to be insulted by the film's insipid cutesy tone that creates a ridiculous fantasy scenario that has no basis in reality.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Those who enjoy sublime naturalism should appreciate Bahrani's latest effort ... though it's just as likely to frustrate those looking for more of a story, one that moves at a more respectable pace
Carlos Cuarón proves his mettle as a director with an amusing and entertaining look at how fame (and soccer) can destroy the bonds of brotherhood.
Hopes for a haunted house thriller that intelligently delves into supernatural territory are usurped by an abundance of cheap scares and a plot derivative of far superior predecessors.
As inspirational as it is heartbreaking, a moving story about pursuing one's dreams and how one can still find a life for oneself even if those dreams don't come to fruition.

In these trying times, it's great to have a positive and uplifting film that perfectly captures the spirit of an era that reminds us that entertainment will always be a way to help us rise above our woes.
A dark and bizarre tone that makes you unsure whether you can laugh, although the dysfunctional characters do eventually win you over.
Tends to get bogged down in an over-abundance of characters and plot developments but does produce enough twists that you never feel cheated by the outcome.
Groundbreaking in terms of its in-depth coverage, but also an incredibly moving portrait of a musical that's as relevant today as it was thirty years ago.
[Attempts to] manipulate the audience's emotions and get them to feel something doesn't work, because it comes across as preachy rather than emotional and moving.
It never quite lives up to the level of filmmaking set by the Disney nature films of yore.
Tatum's limited acting abilities and Montiel's lack of a consistent vision for his film keeps it from ever delivering on a promising central premise.
By no means perfect but a solid effort at condensing a complicated origin story into a satisfying fast-paced action flick.
For a comedy that doesn't require a lot of heavy thinking, it tries hard not to dumb things down too much, nor skimp on character or storytelling either.
Star Trek should quench all your Trekker geek desires, but make no mistake, this is still very much the same Star Trek, just with a younger cast and a lot more money thrown at it.
So far, this is one of the best docs in terms of intelligence and craftsmanship this year.
The awful writing and weak acting keeps the movie from delivering an experience as strong as the original.

The writing is awful and the acting is atrocious, almost on a par with something we might see in the After Dark Horror Fest. I never thought I'd see the day where I fault a zombie movie for being unrealistic.
Goes so far beyond anything we've seen before, that it's often hard to keep up with its brilliance.
Impeccably shot and acted, but essentially a great-looking cliche-filled period film that carries very little weight or emotional impact.
A lot of cool ideas and visuals ... but good luck trying to figure out what's going on.
This powerful drama sometimes loses its way, quite tragically, due to a rare scenery-chewing performance from Julianne Moore
A career-defining performance by Julia Jentsch drives this riveting German thriller
A heartwarming story of redemption sure to win anyone over by the end.
Realistic characters brought to life by dramatic performances so strong you forget you're watching actors.
More than just a concert film, Block Party is a great look into the mind of a comedian, captured at the height of his success.
The most faithful and literal adaptation of an Alan Moore graphic novel...a potent combination of action, emotion and wry political commentary.
Cool martial arts and special effects barely make up for laughably atrocious writing and acting and an obvious sci-fi premise.
As grim, grisly and gratuitous as the original movie, this remake serves about as little purpose.
Tends to delve into the ridiculous due to Vin Diesel's incessant comic schtick...makes it hard to take it seriously.
Goes off on too many tangents from the central story with irrelevant subplots that might actually have been decent movies on their own.
Not since American Psycho's Patrick Bateman has there been a character so despicable and lovable at the same time
Hunter Richards' parade of sex, drugs and pretty young things is saved by the amazing cast of young talent assembled.
A tawdry fictionalized account of Jones' last days, ignoring his contributions to rock to focus on the sex, drugs and controversy
If your own basic instinct is to avoid this movie, then you probably should go with that.
Will get under your skin with an intensity on the verge of being just plain evil.
Even better than Scary Movie 3 ... but is that really saying very much?
Gretchen Mol gives a career-defining performance as the '50s pin-up model
Comes across like a bad 'Saturday Night Live' political sketch, dragged on for way too long ... a lot of great talent wasted.
A genuinely creepy and deeply disturbing experience, as would be expected by fans of the games
Not since Bowling for Columbine has a movie left me so shaken up or so close to tears; that alone is a testament to Greengrass' achievement.
Often tries too hard to tug at the heartstrings, but you'd have to be fairly cold and cynical not to give in.
Probably like nothing you've seen before, but you'd have to be pretty sick and twisted to really get off on it.
The ending is handled so poorly that you forget how much you might have enjoyed the rest of the movie.
Offers some solid laughs, but then gets bogged down in a rather dreary crime drama story that isn't as much fun.
For an inspirational story set in the world of soccer, you could do a heck of a lot worse.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A film about growth and recovery, about finding your way in life after the loss of a loved one and simply one of the best films I've seen this year so far.
Scene-stealing by Gary Marshall and Jeremy Piven does little to salvage a weak, corny satire of the bar-mitzvah ritual.
Death finds gloriously grisly new ways to deal with teenagers who dare to spit in his face.
Dragged down by the flat delivery of a grossly miscast Helen Hunt
Watching Cillian Murphy in drag takes some patience and tolerance but it's actually quite a touching story
As much a love story as a loving musical tribute to the mysterious man in black; a fine achievement in cinematic storytelling
Proves that lame musicals tend to make even lamer movies.
Anyone expecting laughs from this dark holiday comedy will be disappointed by this ho-ho-horrible movie.
Syriana does for the oil industry what Traffic did for the drug trade.
It's depressing to think how much better this could have been in the hands of a skilled director.
Felicity Huffman truly shines in a role that makes you forget she's a man ... er ... woman.
Those who enjoy Jackson's previous films will probably forgive the movie's pacing and storytelling problems once the action kicks into high gear
Dame Judi Dench is utterly delightful in this witty and whimsical crowd pleaser
A gorgeous film, as romantic for its scenery as it is for the central relationship.
You have to appreciate the attention to detail and the beauty imbued into every scene by Rob Marshall and his crew
If The Producers isn't the most perfect movie musical in years, then it comes pretty damn close
Unless you're a 13-year-old girl alone at home, there aren't many scares to be found in this horrible, pointless remake
If this movie doesn't put you in the Christmas spirit, you're either dead...or Jewish.
Mick Taylor should be in the pantheon of classic horror characters along with Leatherface and Freddy Krueger.
Thanks, Mr. Mallick, for 2 1/2 hours of pretentious wanking!
The same bland, lazy filmmaking Allen's been doing for years, only without the humor and with different accents.
Shepard and his terrific cast turns a fairly simple premise into one of those rare buddy comedies that has both brains and heart!
A horrifying excursion into a nightmarish world few of us would ever want to experience firsthand
By bombing in the Muslim world--in the comedic sense--Brooks produces one of his funniest films in years.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film's strengths lie in the way it mixes facts with more personal stories to show both the reasons and the effects of war.
Von Trier's obvious bigotry towards the U.S. and the significantly weaker cast makes his revolutionary ideas a harder sell the second time around.
If you can't guess how the whole thing ends than you clearly haven't seen enough of these movies and probably deserve to sit through another.
Soderbergh creates a ludicrous crime drama that may as well have been redubbed Law and Order: Boring as Sh*t.
Ingenious and genuinely funny...breaks down the fourth wall, and then proceeds to knock down the other thre
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hopkins' delightful performance as the eccentric Burt Munro is the true heart and soul of this highly enjoyable film.
Spielberg [has made a] movie, as if the last thirty years of cinema and world events never occurred.
Intriguing and original...probably too cryptic for those expecting a movie about spelling bees.
Way too long and duller than watching Da Vinci's paint dry...takes away the book's little credibility and makes the flaws more obvious.
Grim and dreary, this depressing drama seems to serve very little purpose...
The fine line between fiction and reality are put to the test in this unconventional thriller, which is elevated by Toni Colette's performance.
The central betting game makes up for the contrived pretensions of trying to make it look like a black and white classic.
A tedious and often emotionally manipulative opportunity to stand on a soapbox and wave the flag.
Honestly, this is a waste of precious DV tapes.
movie_title: The Trouble With Men and Women (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Leaves a lasting impression due to the three solid performances from Gosling, Mackie and newcomer Shareeka Epps.
Might never have worked if not for the personality, charm and palpable chemistry between its two leads.
Often more haunting and disturbing for what you don't see than for what you do.

A joyful conclusion to the underrated series and a true coup for Klepisch that he was able to end the series on such a high.
Owen and Binoche bring so much to the story as a whole that it's hard not to be won over once it gets past the rom-com cliches we've seen so many times before.
Never relies solely on its tasty-looking food to win over the audience ... and yet, it's probably the best 'foodie' movie since Ratatouille.
A nice mix of old school romance with an inside look at the world of con men and pick pockets, which ultimately does make for an entertainment film.
One of the best prison dramas you're likely to see in some time, but the real stand-out is the introduction of Jack O'Connell
Shawn Levy's cast often makes up for the routineness of the film's overused premise.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fails to convey the material in a particularly creative or inventive way with Waltz's constant scenery-chewing detracting from any insight the story tries to offer.
Easily one of the most important and relevant films of the year.
Maintains the snarkiness of Mark Millar's writing, while creating something on a much grander scale.
A Most Violent Year is Chandor's take on The Godfather or Scarface, though it's not quite as thrilling or memorable as those classics.
It tends to drag in setting up what may be one of the most unsatisfying and aggravating plot twists in recent memory.
This time around, the only thing getting taken is your money.
Hard as it tries, The Wedding Ringer is spectacularly unfunny.
Fans of previous submarine thrillers should appreciate the tense nail-biter that Macdonald has created.
A grueling experience to sit through if you're not in on the central joke and Rauch's character.
Another comedy that tries too hard for laughs and ends up with a batting average below 50%.
Not a particularly mainstream film, but it's certainly one that will appeal to the arthouse crowd who appreciates character-based storytelling.
A thought-provoking experience that never feels bogged down in its dialogue.
Avoids the typical bombast of the normal crime thriller, instead focusing its efforts at being a densely-scripted character study.
The amount of laughs Patrick Brice is able to generate from such a simple idea and on such a small budget makes one think that he's due for a breakout.
Baumbach and Gerwig came up with the simplest of concepts and then threw in as many ideas as possible rather than trying to do things that might enhance the overall story.
Doesn't really offer anything unique or special that we haven't seen before, basically squandering its talented stars.
There aren't a ton of significant moments as it essentially rolls along and follows their journey to find out if Polly can get pregnant.
Will have a significant impact on anyone who watches it, regardless of whether they've been personally affected by cancer.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Swanberg has created a lovely film that it's hard to find anything to not like about it, but it also never tries to be anything more than what sets it out to be.
A grim and depressing movie that's painfully dull, making it hard to recommend it even for fans of Silverman who want to see her stretch her dramatic acting muscles.
Such a strong piece that I would not even be remotely surprised if this is being talked about at year's end, come awards time.
A perfectly pleasant mix of humor and drama that will remind you how much Lily Tomlin is missed as a regular fixture in movies.
While this is going to be a polarizing and divisive film, it's one that people will talk about after seeing it, almost as if it was made as an experiment itself.
The Seinfeld of this year's Sundance, basically a movie with a lot of talking about nothing.
Some aspects might be off-putting, but the actors and filmmakers handle the topic in a surprisingly tasteful way.
Fans of the original movie may be more forgiving of the weak storytelling and the awkward performances that make up this lackluster sequel.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's so nice to have this fantastic filmmaking couple back and regaining their stride with such a different film for them.
Despite a strong cast, it's obvious where the problems lie: a weak script and a director working beyond his ability to make the movie work dramatically.
Hilarious, but it's probably going to get us nuked.
Reese Witherspoon and the unconventional way Strayed's story is told goes a long way to create a far more lasting experience.
A perfectly respectable crime-drama that's only hindered by the fact it feels redundant to a genre that's already become fairly oversaturated.
Has such a good heart that you leave the theater smiling, which is not something we get very often nowadays.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful and inspirational story, and a real filmmaking coup for Curran which should be getting a far more high-profile release than it's being given.
A refreshing change from other musical biopics as it shows other sides to the rock legend that we haven't had a chance to see before.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What may be one of Jason Schwartzman's funniest roles to date.
An ambitious look at a very specific time that works better than other similar attempts.
A forgettable non-event ... almost as aggravating as David Cronenberg's A Dangerous Method.
For those who expect cinematic mastery from everything David Fincher does, this doesn't seem like anything special compared to his high watermarks.
Another fine step forward for Jason Reitman as a filmmaker, although for some, the film's message may be a little on-point.
Few movies can achieve the highest benchmark of 'perfection,' and movies like Whiplash only come along once in a blue moon.
P.T. Anderson's most uninspired work to date and mostly a worthless waste of time.
May be hard to wrap one's head around, but it's easily one of the most thought-provoking films of the past ten years, maybe more.
Chris Rock never loses sight of the laughs for his most personal film yet.
Quite an achievement for director David Ayer in creating something far more expansive and cinematic than some of his earlier films.
Shows another side to Snowden and the reasons for what he did in a fairly unedited fashion and that's largely what makes it the perfect coda to Snowden's story.
Nolan's love letter to space travel and the exploration of the stars may require some patience, but it offers an incredible emotional payoff along with its visual spectacle.
Absolutely intense, a fantastic debut by Dan Gilroy with Gyllenhaal giving an unforgettable performance that shows him achieving the next level as an actor.
Definitely a movie to see for true fans of British music, as it shows another layer of the punk and post-punk music scene that should be appreciated.
A brilliant and beautiful film that gives us a more personal and intimate look at this amazing genius of a man than we've ever seen before.
The slow pace won't be for everyone, but watching three actors give such riveting performances in the telling of such a fascinating character piece more than makes up for it.
Prince-Blythewood's attempt to create authenticity in a story set within the music business is elevated by having solid actors like Gugu Mbatha-Raw and Nate Parker to bolster it.
A disappointing follow-up to 'Catching Fire.' You're left feeling as if you've only watched half a movie without the same feeling of anticipation to see what happens next.
A lazy and uninspired attempt that barely captures or recreates why the first movie was so hilarious.
A riveting and emotional historical piece that bolsters one of the best performances of the year by Benedict Cumberbatch.
Another grand spectacle that does a fine job wrapping things up without offering nearly as many of the memorable moments of its predecessor.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jack O'Connell's performance and the fantastic work done by Jolie and her team make this a far more effective story than one might expect.
Corny, dumb and predictable and rife with clichés, it's Dawson's Crap.
We have to assume, even hope, that a movie this bad will finally wring the death knell for found footage horror... but sadly we'd probably be wrong.
An oppressive onslaught of noises and colors, occasionally punctuated by a joke.
The film also captures the ups and downs of the band that sometimes felt like they were cursed.
movie_title: The Damned: Don't You Wish That We Were Dead (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The fluid mix of genres and tones helps make Their Finest better than many other period films of its ilk.
Another gorgeous film from Gray, The Lost City of Z is a great step forward in his career.
There has never been a movie about this subject matter handled in such an honest, personal and funny way.
Clumsily wedges a romantic triangle into the gritty story of the Armenian genocide ... never really gives you much reason to care about the characters.
An intensive look inside the way one of the country's most prestigious newspapers works.
A distinctive approach to movie storytelling and keeps you invested, mainly because Malek is such a compelling actor.
Marc Myers' innovative look at a serial killer as a high school outcast is a welcome twist on the genre.
There's also little question that the movie is frequently saved by offering another joyously entertaining performance by Christopher Plummer.
May be one of this year's most important and significant documentaries.
Laura Poitras offers a worthwhile look at WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange that somehow still feels half-finished.
A fairly standard, thinly plotted martial-arts film that purports to elevate women in that arena, but instead demeans them with weak, clichéd storytelling.
Scott has effectively created a satisfying hybrid of Alien, Prometheus and even James Cameron's Aliens.
An embarrassing, unfunny movie that leaves a bad blemish on the late careers of its stars.
A very weak high concept thriller that gets worse the further it goes into its god awful premise.
Disturbing and jarring ... but masterfully directed and acted.
A really pleasant and joyous film that definitely has a Bridget Jones quality to it.
The most obvious of humor and weakest of plots lead this road comedy based on Jeff Kinney's popular books down a dead end.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A weak, uninspired thriller, offering a frustrating and implausible twist instead of anything in the way of tension.
A fairly comprehensive and thorough portrait of a band whose legacy has far surpassed its drug-tinged hippie roots.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dead Men Tell No Tales is flawed, but it's still better than Marshall's film and the weirdness that overpowered and eventually ruined Verbinski's original trilogy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jenkins (and Gadot) particularly excel in the action scenes, because when Wonder Woman first runs across the battlefields in her costume, you are immediately won over.
Captain Underpants' unquenchable desire to make kids laugh is ultimately what wins you over with its charm.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Often scarier for what it doesn't say or show, which may also make it somewhat frustrating, since you're never sure exactly what's happening either.
Ultimately, The Mummy isn't absolutely terrible... there's a lot of potential here that's been squandered by including Cruise and Crowe.
Despite treading far-too-familiar territory, The Hunter's Prayer is a surprisingly solid action thriller that should appeal to fans of Luc Besson's earlier movies.
Demetrius Shipp Jr. gives it his all with an impressive performance that's far more than just an impression.
Such a fun and funny movie about a long-time friendship that's put to the test through a road trip.
By the finale, there's way too much happening on screen, to the point where no one will be able to figure out what they're watching.
Shot! is an absolutely essential doc for anyone interested in the amazing era of rock music produced during the 1970s.
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, it's a fairly sweet and enjoyable film.
This is a far more fun and family-friendly superhero universe than what we normally get.
If you loved the original movie, you might not care so much about being given warmed-over seconds. Otherwise, this Wick has burned itself out.
The actors are so good that it doesn't even seem awkward when the film gives us a romantic angle between Nicholson's Sophie and the Japanese visitor.
A perfectly harmless family film that's about as challenging and interesting as Saturday morning television fare, and yet, better than expected.
Takes its sweet time before audiences can connect to it in the way the filmmaker intended, but ultimately the emotional content of the last act wins you over.
Hugh Jackman's last Wolverine story ends on a grim, gritty and ultra-violent note that wins points both for being cinematic and for being so different.
Peele takes the concept behind Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? to its furthest, most genre extreme.
If you're a fan of genre films, especially things like Danny Boyle's 28 Days Later, then this is definitely a movie you'll want to check out.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Poorly conceived and executed, it doesn't even feel like something that can be laughed about when it shows up on cable... which will probably be very soon.
Kris Avedisian's undeniably quirky charm in the title role helps steer this indie buddy comedy away from the usual clichés.
An important message ... buried under platitudes, sermons and a saccharine score that endlessly plucks at the heart strings.
A popcorn movie that's only good as long as you still have popcorn left in your tub, and is quickly forgotten after you've run out.
An exceedingly warm and wonderful family drama from filmmaker Marc Webb.
One of Freundlich's career best, just an amazing achievement in creating a movie that keeps you on edge...
Works well as a movie meant to provoke thought and discussion with a capitol 'P.'
No, the main duo isn't the problem as much as it is the bad writing and a lot of the cast around them.
An interesting character study and a nice book-end to the original Trainspotting.
An absolutely fantastic film from Ozon ... easily Ozon's most striking and solid films in years.
An amusing show-slash-movie, with the caveat being that you really need to be able to endure Zahedi's nerdy and neurotic persona to be able to fully appreciate his work.
A welcome addition to the genre, although it is slower and more grounded in reality than the science fiction movies to which modern audiences have become accustomed.

It's a convoluted mess that zig-zags all over the map, but there are enough jokes that connect to keep you along for the ride.
A contemplative Malick-like drama that leans heavily on its Iceland locations and the genuine chemistry between its two young actors.
An outlandish, overly complicated premise that's likely to confound the kiddies while it tries hard to get laughs from their parents.
Fans of the original comics should appreciate how faithful it remains to them. It's a very pretty movie that pulls you into this futuristic world.
A brilliant must-watch documentary whether you're Jewish or a fan of comedy and how/why it does or doesn't work.
In the end, this latest "Rings" sequel is just inexcusably bad.
Ripped is not a good film, yet it's also a movie that's difficult to completely hate.
A grand entry into more straightforward American genre film-mixing by Wright, while still maintaining all the things we've loved about his previous movies.
A twisty redneck genre flick that partially thrives on its odd stoner humor, then loses something as it shifts to something far darker.
A fascinating doc just being able to see how things really work within the police department compared to what we see in press conferences and through the media.
A welcome return to form for Dayton and Faris
[C.K.] has made the type of masterful picture that might put him into serious consideration as a filmmaker...
It's a decent character piece for Washington to break away from that same cocksure role we've seen him play so many times before

A decent, highly informational doc that takes a lighter look at a subject some might take far more seriously than others.
Wonderstruck is probably the biggest disappointment in Todd Haynes' entire career. How one can go from the masterpiece that was Carol or any of his other films to this is mindboggling.
With nothing particularly new or revelatory to offer, Haze is a terrible, pointless movie.
It's the type of action movie that just feels dated and not in a fun way either.
Friend Request is either the funniest bad horror movie ever made or, more likely, just a bad movie that was never meant to be a comedy.
Neither Allen's best movie nor his worst, although it's probably a stronger than his last few, mainly due to Winslet's fabulousness.
Betts proves herself to be a fantastic storyteller ... Intense and riveting dramatic storytelling we rarely get to see in any given year.
Won't be for everyone, and some people are going to absolutely loathe it, but it's a lovely artistic character exploration that is quite compelling when you're willing to go along for the ride.
A faithful adaptation of a classic manga that drags at times but offers enough exciting moments at others to make it worthwhile.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The embarrassment a few fine, august actors have to go through in the name of 'comedy' is lost on a movie that never warrants a single laugh.
A triumph by Rees as a filmmaker, showing she can handle a wide range of characters and settings to create a cohesive story.
A mishmash of decent action scenes smooshed into a weak revenge-thriller premise that only comes together towards the end.
While not horrible, [it] feels like such a wasted opportunity to end on a high note rather than merely petering away.
There's certainly good to be found in the story Winchester is trying to tell, but it's hard to believe it can possibly satisfy both the casual horror buff and the more diehard supernatural purist.
It's impossible to watch [this| and not consider it one of the best films of 2017.
The Strangers: Prey at Night isn't terrible, but that's mainly due to Roberts' skills as a filmmaker and the film's climactic final act.
There's nothing particularly groundbreaking here in terms of storytelling, and it seems like a fairly trivial waste of its two leads.
Kids will absolutely adore and thrill to this adventure, but it will sneak up on grown-ups who will eventually be dazzled both by the beauty of the visuals and the masterful storytelling.

Loads of fun, Baby Driver gives a great ride.

I'm going to end this review on some sort of hyperbolic pull quote that will look good on Twitter and/or RottenTomatoes that can be used in the film's marketing.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The best-realized Spider-Man movie in terms of making the character current with what's been done with Marvel Studios' other movies...
An intriguing exploration of fate vs. circumstance and coincidence that ends up being far better than it should be, but only if it's not taken too seriously.
A mind-numbing premise that's often embarrassing to its illustrious cast.
Like The Fifth Element, this will grow on people with time ... meant more for discerning moviegoers with strange taste and sensibilities.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

It seems content at being just another Saturday Night Live short.
Never goes far enough to truly scare anyone. Even easy-to-please teens might wish for their time back.
A prime candidate for worst movie of the year.
There's so much to absorb and appreciate in this movie that one viewing just might not be enough.

movie_title: Who The F**k Is That Guy? The Fabulous Journey of Michael Alago (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One thing Power mostly gets right is that he spends enough time with both the predators and their victims, separately, so that you start to care for the latter even if you don't fully understand the motivations of the former.
Darkest Hour showcases a performance by Gary Oldman that is so good, you'll often forget you're watching an actor working from a script.
A suitably punky, fast-paced doc that may be long and overly talky but is undeniably comprehensive.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lowlife features a lot of amazing new talent that's likely to make this a popular cult hit.
Takes filmmaking incompetence to a whole new level.
This bona-fide grindhouse film constantly goes for violent and gory shock value, yet manages to connect more through its hilarious female characters.
An erratic but emotional adaptation of Jeannette Wallis' memoir.

An above-average, obscenity-laden buddy comedy that mostly excels due to the brilliant comic pairing of Ryan Reynolds and Samuel L. Jackson.
Aspects of the film recalls the early work of Damien Chazelle. If Jasper can continue to deliver on this level, his career may wind up being just as impressive.
A brilliantly made film, unlike anything else out there, and it teaches a valuable lesson about what the penal system's cycle of violence can do to an honest man.
Mopey and pretentious, just like the real Morrissey, but lacking the music that made his work with The Smiths so influential.
After a summer full of disappointing sequels, it shouldn't be too much of a surprise that we're getting yet another.
A beautiful film documenting some of the most groundbreaking rock music of the '70s and the major contribution Mick Ronson offered well beyond being "Bowie's guitar player."
movie_title: Beside Bowie: The Mick Ronson Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Good luck understanding how any of this might appeal to modern moviegoers. It isn't awful, but it's needlessly convoluted and dull, dull, dull.
Fans of John Wick and Kill Bill should generally be impressed with what director Jung has done to put a twist on the typical revenge thriller.
Well-rounded portrait of a talented celebrity DJ, whose potential was taken away by drug addiction.
movie_title: As I AM: The Life and Times of DJ AM (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rings does little to improve upon a tired horror idea that's been done better by other filmmakers, making it aggravatingly redundant.
Moronic lowbrow stoner humor and two of the most annoying characters ever put onscreen make this a grueling experience.
A wonderful surprise.
Dull at times but otherwise fine, this fantasy remake tends to excel from the realism instilled into its animated title character.
Won't be for everyone, but if nothing else, you'll never look at your groceries the same way again.
Mel Gibson makes a brilliant return to the revenge-thriller genre with a surprisingly strong effort.
Imperium is a stark character drama that's more disconcerting for its subject matter than its actual storytelling.
Equally clever and charming, and ultimately a pretty good date movie in its own right.
The type of edge-of-your seat thrills promised by its commercials, but also takes you into far darker territory than anticipated.
With stunning photorealistic animation but poor storytelling, this action movie is meant solely to interest fans of the videogame franchise.
One of the most enjoyable films of the year.
One of the more intriguing German films that sadly won't get nearly as much attention here as it deserves.
movie_title: The People vs. Fritz Bauer (Der Staat Gegen Fritz Bauer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: ... A pleasant enough experience in which you should easily be able to find someone or something to relate to in it.
A very accessible and relatable movie about family and how one family pulls together to try to fight against adversity with love and laughs.
An even more relatable story of real-world people and the troubles in which we frequently find ourselves.
As funny as it ends up being, it's also quite thought-provoking, because it makes you think about whether you're satisfied with your own relationships
It's more than a little ironic that a film called Complete Unknown will leave you scratching your head about what you just watched.
The sequel to the Danish comedy duo's breakout hit fails to find the same degree of laughs.
Chris Reading's attempt at a lower-budget space thriller suffers as much from its lack of originality as it does from its weak cast and script.
A distinctly authentic-feeling coming-of-age story that introduces a bright new visionary filmmaker in Justin Tipping.

Filmmaker J.A. Bayona goes three for three with A Monster Calls, a movie more steeped in fantasy and fairy tale than his previous one.
A cerebral and emotionally resonant examination of language through the genre of science fiction.

Peter Berg's masterful disaster flick will shake you up with its accuracy.
Chazelle creates something absolutely unforgettable. Few people will be able to see this movie only once.
Simply one of the best historic musical docs you're likely to see.

movie_review_blurb: If you're remotely interested in America's space program, this will be a fun movie to watch.

movie_title: Space Dogs: Adventure to the Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It feel more like you're watching real lives and events rather than a big bombastic movie with lots of overwrought drama.

A moving and inspirational story of strength and perseverance in the face of tremendous adversity.
The Lonely Island at their best and a brilliantly clever successor to This is Spinal Tap.
If you're a serious horror fan, then you absolutely must add The Wailing to your must-see list this year.

As with the best popcorn flicks, Out of the Shadows offers plenty of mindless entertainment and mind-numbing silliness...

movie_review_blurb: The ghost busters of The Conjuring 2 are scary good.
Probably good enough that if you liked the first movie, you'll want to check this one out as well.

Seems to talk down to all but the youngest of children, making it grueling for adults to find anything to keep them invested.
Needless to say Swiss Army Man isn't going to be for everyone.

A wonderful slice of New Zealand-bred humor that should have a far wider appeal than Waititi's previous films.
Li Lu's bland road movie is barely salvaged by the talents of its star, Agnes Bruckner.
movie_title: There Is a New World Somewhere (2016)

A B-grade action movie filled with racist, homophobic and sexist humor, knowing its audience is likely to eat it up.
Our Kind of Traitor tries to sell itself as a classic British espionage thriller, but with spy work this boring, this isn't our kind of movie.
After three disturbingly violent films, this may be a concept that deserves to be purged.
Fairly harmless and innocuous, but also only as funny as your tolerance for the overuse of Borg's idiotic shenanigans.

A surprisingly fun summer comedy and icing on the (wedding) cake for fans of the raunchiest of humor.

A deeply emotional film about loss that will probably have you crying by film's end.

Ventures into some corny (yet sweet) territory in resolving its central conflict, but it throws enough laughs at the viewer that at least some of them land.
