movie_review_blurb: A dull, depressing exercise in amateurism from a filmmaker in serious decline.
A great goofy delight, a dandy mix of energetic performances, inspired sight gags and flat-out silliness.
The dreamiest Jesse James ever, looking less like a bandit and more like the grand prize in my sister's old 'Mystery Date' board game.
The movie is entertainingly bad.
Sets out to be a classic ghost story, but fails to grasp that special something that makes such films more than layers of mist.
This is a bumpy ride.
Gives us another chance to experience the skewed vision of Tim Burton.
The film offers no grand statements, just a clever idea and exceptional cast.
As a Hollywood satire, America's Sweethearts is toothless. As a romance, it is at best a minor pleasure.
Bright, busy and visually diverting, but not very much fun.

Witnessing De Niro, Norton, Brando and Bassett act in this film is like watching Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa play softball. You're not sure why they're doing it, but you wouldn't miss the game for anything.
Despite the idiotic people, the absurd level of coincidence, the spotty special effects and the lazy ending, I still liked Jurassic Park III.
The filmmakers clearly realize they are making a formulaic, crowd-pleasing girl power movie and they know how to do it.
Rush Hour 2 isn't as good as the original, but it offers more than enough entertainment to warrant your time and money.
Surrounds a weird, funny and touching story with a knockout series of songs performed by an exceptional cast.
Jeepers Creepers may sputter in the last reel, but it still delivers enough style and scares to warrant a look by horror aficionados.
Inoffensive, but utterly generic, the baseball-related romantic comedy does little more than kill time.
For those who marvel at dinosaurs, this is an absolute must-see.
Plays as primarily an academic exercise, engaging the eyes, ears and intellect, but not the heart.
If you're the kind of person that questions the fantastic and expects a story to respect its own logic, then you should take some aspirin before seeing this movie.
The film is a silly, pretentious and generally entertaining yarn about the pissing war between a fallen leader and a wannabe.
While the film sags in spots, it is remarkably rich and robust, with a wealth of memorable performances.
Ups the fear factor by adding an anonymous figure, one that cannot be reasoned with, whose only goal is to get his hands on you.
A windy, moderately entertaining trifle. You could do a lot worse than "Bandits," but the filmmakers could have done much better.
These are frightening, uncertain times and there is something soothing about watching a movie and knowing exactly what is going to happen.
Those able to withstand the intensity and violence will be rewarded with solid acting by Ethan Hawke and a towering performance from Denzel Washington.
I found Bully absolutely riveting.
Purports to show the incalculable impact a mentor can have on a child, but offers a contradictory message through its depiction of the adult version of that child.
The story degenerates steadily and finally becomes just another horror show with a psycho chasing adolescents.
The Deep End is an exceptional film and Tilda Swinton is the best part of it.
A minor pleasure, with a strong first half, a tepid second half and a hell of a performance from Mark Wahlberg.
Beneath the sappy music and formulaic story, the core of the film rang true.
We've got a movie about a futuristic city that doesn't spend much time in the futuristic city, instead focusing on a road trip/chase plot line with mostly uninteresting characters.
An ethical thriller about two men whose biggest enemy is not each other, but their unwillingness to take responsibility for their own actions.
Now here's something you don't see everyday: a movie title that matches the number of stars most critics are going to give to it.
A breezy romantic comedy that has the punch of a good sitcom, while offering exceptionally well-detailed characters.
Locke is a great looking and sounding tale of a man's (misguided?) quest to do the right thing.

The Theory of Everything offers interesting characters and standout acting. I wish it had delved deeper into its characters, but for what it is -- a romance involving one of the great minds of humanity -- it's engaging and moving.
Hoffman is in fine form here and, despite a long murky stretch, the film works.
It's colorful and fun, a good, but not great Disney cartoon.
The Drop is an atmospheric crime story with fine performances, especially from star Tom Hardy. As for the plot - well, it keeps the characters busy.
The black and white images are beautifully composed, the classic "Academy" square screen ratio adds to the atmosphere and the music is sparse and effective.
Citizenfour deserves your attention.
I had a better time than I expected.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Love is Strange is lovely, painful and universal.
I had more fun watching Guardians of the Galaxy than I've had in a long time.
I've been bullied and I've been a bully, and I don't enjoy watching it onscreen. I loved Whiplash, though.
More a character study than a thriller, Nightcrawler is well-acted and compelling.
Some may find it too outlandish, but it never fails to remain interesting.
Is Birdman an indictment of Hollywood for playing to the crowds? That would be odd coming from a movie stuffed with camera gimmicks, eye candy, dirty jokes and stunt casting.
Life Itself is an exceptional look at this exceptional man. Wouldn't it have been interesting to read Ebert's assessment of the film?
Rock's best work yet.
Reeves is charismatic and kind of otherworldly, and the stunts are shot and presented clearly enough that you can tell what's going on. What else do you need?
The adaptation of John Green's best-selling young adult novel gets downright gloppy at times, even as Hazel and Augustus strive to remain brave and unsentimental. But it touched my heart and mind.
The film loses steam whenever it shifts from the teen killers to the adult pair investigating the crime.
Director Thomas Vinterberg crafts a handsome film, then lets the string section goo everything up.

[I] loved most of the exchanges between the characters. Appreciated the Avengers' attempts to avoid destruction in population centers. The action scenes were very exciting and clever, but I had trouble keeping up with the visuals.
Powerhouse dystopian chase film/thriller/political statement from Alfonso Cuarón.

It would've been nice to tell you Insurgent was surprisingly good. Or fun to rant and rave about how lousy it is. But no. It's just there, another middle installment of another teen-targeted post-apocalyptic series.
You don't have to be a Star Trek fan to enjoy this rollicking movie. J.J. Abrams' reboot of the 1966 TV space adventure series is fast-paced, action-packed and lots of fun.
The rich, dark production is the 25th directorial turn by Clint Eastwood and is perhaps his best work yet.
The movie pays off so well because it places you fully in the shoes of the men, from their fears and obsessions to their paranoia about virtually every Iraqi citizen they encounter.
Crash is the best film I've seen so far this year.
Danny Boyle and company have crafted a film that feels like a project of citizens of the world, not outsiders looking in.

No Country for Old Men is wide and dusty and terribly bleak. It's beautifully photographed and assembled, with great performances from its lead players and a number of welcome appearances by actors we haven't seen enough of lately.
One of the very best films of 2011.
The shocking violence is well-placed. The action scenes are always comprehensible -- no jump cut cheats here -- and the suspense will make you fidget in your seat. What a corker.

Even though the ending is well known, Affleck masterfully maintains the tension, tempering it with welcome laughs provided by two veteran filmmakers involved in the scheme (Alan Arkin and John Goodman).
12 Years a Slave is the clearest view of slavery I've seen onscreen.
Joyeux Noel is a fascinating piece of work that manages to be moving without becoming maudlin.
The film offers grand visuals, including a bizarre-beautiful key scene in a location I couldn't describe if I wanted to.
Writer-director Gillian Robespierre and star Jenny Slate team up to create a fine portrait of a twenty-something comedian dealing with life as a struggling performer in New York City.
Pulses with fascinating ideas, memorable images and thrilling action sequences.
Powerful, disturbing, funny, thought provoking, moving and infuriating.
Too busy, with too many characters and too much going on. Still, the film retains enough charm to offset the excess.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the film is quite entertaining, mixing scares with welcome bits of humor, but the ending fizzles.
Lower your expectations. A lot. No, more than that.
Adam Sandler is an extremely likable man who knows his limitations and works within them.
I am so sick of watching filmmakers "honor" soldiers by blowing them up creatively.
Although there are many juicy supporting performances, Christina Ricci owns this movie. What a wonderful talent, and what a maddening, but enjoyable film.
"Scooby Doo" is, God help us, a faithful adaptation of the wretched series.
Grant is letter perfect in a role that would have been ruined by one misstep. What a treat it is to watch such a gifted performer work.
A thoroughly enjoyable "B" Movie all trussed up in "A" Movie trappings.
Brash, funny, sexually frank and extremely smart.
Derailed by an idiotic, utterly needless plot gimmick.
The scenery is gorgeous, the mood is upbeat and your traveling companions are interesting fellows.
The kind of romance that makes a life of solitude seem attractive. The kind of life-affirming story that makes the prospect of death a little less daunting.
Well, it's not as bad as the last one.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Better than Generations and Insurrection, but not as good as First Contact.
Snappier than the first.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: 'Civil War battle re-enactment scenes surrounded by the longest high school play ever.'

Moneyball looks like an underdog sports movie, but it veers away from the path usually followed by films of the genre. My suggestion is that you set aside any preconceptions and just go with the flow.
Lotfy Nathan's hand-held camerawork, combined with a snappy hip-hop soundtrack, gives the documentary a sense of immediacy.

Jasmine is a good movie, one of Allen's best in years, but the draw here is Blanchett, whose performance takes an off-putting character and makes her surprisingly, um ... not quite on-putting, but riveting.
One thing's for sure. You won't see another documentary like this one.
I didn't find Somebody Up There Likes Me as funny as others seem to, but I was fascinated enough by the curious offering to watch it twice.
Timberlake and Kunis do a good job with an old routine, and Woody keeps the proceedings lively. As rom-coms go, you could do a lot worse than this.
Finding Nemo is a triumph, with a different, richer feel than any previous Pixar film. Aided by a smart, evocative score by Thomas Newman, the story is funny, moving and completely engrossing.
'A Biblical snuff film'
Shaky in spots, but rewarding overall.
Testosterone-filled fun
Lower your expectations and you'll likely have some fun.
'The main asset is Kurt Russell, who is extraordinary.'
'A rewrite - one that played more off the straight-laced vs. laid-back dynamic rather than racial stereotypes - would have helped.'
'Hamlet in crayon, with rats.'
'Sloppy, but it delivers big laughs on a consistent basis.'
French director Robert Bresson used his nonactors only once and orchestrated every gesture and glance; the performances that resulted are both mesmerizing and suffused with mystery.
The final-reel development, for instance, relies on a coincidence so monstrous I'm surprised it survived the script's second draft (if there was one).
Much of this unflinchingly observed film - titled Dreamcatcher and named after Brenda's organisation - has the flavour of a nightmare.
It's savagely funny stuff.
A sprawling, often provocative exploration of the ethics and competing interests involved in the coverage of a case like Elizabeth's murder.
It impresses less for its originality than for its bold execution. This is a seductively stylised, boldly directed and alluringly performed film, a work of languorous cool and dreamy soulfulness.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Given [that the film] is concerned with the rigid certainties of algebraic formulation, its winning formula -- mixing charm, low-key humour, on-screen chemistry and emotional delicacy -- is altogether more ineffable.
You sense Maysles recognises a kindred spirit in Iris' undimmed curiosity about the world, and her restless creative drive. It's the perfect introduction to his remarkable body of work.
White God, quite aside from its allegorical aspects, is on its own terms impressively original cinema, combining tense and subtle moments of human drama with thrillingly muscular action set-pieces.
The result is a gripping blend of psychological drama and epic adventure, brutal and bloody but underpinned with a delicate lyricism. Barely saying a word, DiCaprio is extraordinary.

It is, of course, a tale with all sorts of sorry implications for the kids but what's so wonderful about The Wolfpack is the attention it devotes to the resilience and imaginative ingenuity the Angulo offspring developed as they were growing up.
It's witty, boisterous and immensely likeable, but don't mistake its considerable charm and slick elegance for superficiality.

Crafted with elegant assurance, Slow West is a film to savour, an authentic throwback to a classic American genre. The achievement is all the more impressive for being filmed in New Zealand by a Scottish director.
Drawing artfully from a tradition of European erotic films of the 1970s, Strickland has fashioned a provocative parable about power and sexuality, ageing and love. Plus, it's deliciously kinky.
The results play like a parable about greed and its distorting impact; but, directed with sombre assurance by Bennett Miller, they grip like a thriller.
With an immensely sympathetic performance from Witherspoon, Wild is a quietly uplifting and delicately moving film about the transformative potential of nature.

A diverting exposé of the frippery of film folk alternates with a moving look at grief in all its everyday profundity; scenes of comedy shift to reveal a tragic undertow -- these are hard things to pull off but Mia Madre does them with quiet authority.
This is a defiantly political film about solidarity, loyalty to workmates and presenting a common front when jobs are threatened.
From out of the (climatic and mood-enhancing) fog of Inherent Vice something strange and rather glorious emerges.

The Big Short does such a good job of shining a light into the dark crevices of financial mismanagement it almost performs a public service -- but in the form of whip-smart, wildly irreverent entertainment.
Hulmes' film is intelligent and original, a debut of promise.
It satisfies with the nourishing warmth of a cup of sweet, milky tea Eilis may find herself longing for in New York, a comforting taste of home in an unfamiliar land.
What emerges is a toxic fairytale about the beauty of artistic endeavour and the beastly behaviour that sometimes accompanies it.

With vertiginous helmet-mounted point-of-views of the slow crawl upwards, the film gives a terrifyingly immediate sense of the dangers the Sherpas face in order to make the trek ready for their wealthy clients.
Listen Up Philip is an astute, quietly complex and richly absorbing study of creative success, with note-perfect performances from a superb ensemble.

Yes, there's humour here, lugubrious and jet black, but it is allied to a vision of human nature as unrelenting bleakness. I love Andersson's work but watching his films can be excruciating: do you laugh or issue a howl of despair?
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While The Tribe often makes for troubling, confrontational viewing, it is ferociously engaging. Stripped of dialogue, this is cinema of high-wire purity: muscular, precise, emotionally complex -- and surprisingly easy to follow.
Like Electro plugging himself into any available energy source, the effect is momentarily impressive. Sparks fly. The air crackles. But the power soon drains -- and nothing quite works as it should.
8 1/2 is one of the great films about filmmaking.

Exciting though the races are, the film is most powerful as a tribute to Dream's many owners and to the community spirit -- dare I say solidarity -- of these working-class folk urging their horse to beat the odds.
12 Years a Slave puts things straight -- and some. Anchored by Chiwetel Ejiofor's performance of contained fortitude as Solomon, the film depicts almost unrelenting institutional brutality.
This is documentary film-making of the highest order -- urgent, necessary and deeply compassionate viewing.
45 Years is an understated, restrained film but its impact is unnerving and haunting.
How to Change the World is in clear sympathy with the environmental causes Greenpeace champions but its portrait of the organisation is quite spiky and probing.
Thanks to a performance of wintry ferocity and dark charisma from Pacino, Manglehorn remains a fascinating enigma.
The stunning location photography stays with you much longer than the script's shortcomings. The mountain, as ever, has the last word.
The result is a compellingly flesh-and-blood depiction of King; an absorbingly sophisticated account of his brand of non-violent activism.
It's an intelligent, sometimes daring film, with a commanding central performance by Michael Fassbender. But this is no puff job.
A clever reworking of a literary classic.
An absorbing portrait of a complex man and an intelligent dissection of the underexamined art of acting.
We should be thankful for the wit and style of Joaquín Oristrell's film.
At one point, jealous Thurman tosses a live shark into Matt and Hannah's love nest. Unwittingly plunged into this farrago, the shark earns my sympathy.

Chappelle keeps things lively, joking on camera, punctuating the acts with gags , while Michel Gondry maintains our interest, focusing as much on Chappelle's energy and wit, and goings-on behind the scenes, as the gig itself.
The American Perabo (doing a good English accent) and Headey are likable leads -- and Goode brings a touching vulnerability to his role as the luckless Heck.
A stirring movie about the ameliorative power of justice and mercy in a fascinating part of the world.
Although Chinatown writer Towne lovingly depicts the Depression-era LA setting (actually shot in South Africa), the film misfires.
A welcome new beginning.

It goes without saying that much of this is pathologically puerile, relentlessly unedifying and in dubious taste, but there are more than enough compensating laugh-out-loud moments (for this viewer, at least).
A sparkling romcom.
Predictable at every turn, glossy but stagy, and full of unengaging, underdeveloped characters, Gossip too is 'all just words'.
An inglorious wreck of a movie.
Chuck & Buck is a film which you can't quite get a fix on: it's a movie about child sex which is also as airy and sweetly likeable as anything you'll see this year.
In trying too hard to convince us what good eggs his characters are, Cole creates a shapeless, dramatically unengaging movie.
An ambitious multi-plotted portrait of overlapping lives in contemporary Mexico City, Amores perros rarely relaxes its grip.
This is narrative film-making stripped of unnecessary detail or fabricated sentiment, and it's all the better for it: Spotlight is absorbing and revelatory.
Possibly a very shallow work, but it's also exhaustively imaginative and bustles with wit and invention.
Loach has made a film of uncompromising, wintry bleakness, haunted by death and ravaged ideals. The days of hope have never been shorter.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The plotting lacks a necessary sense of tragic propulsion; it feels dutifully schematic, its ironies polite and tidy when they should be bitter and merciless.
A superior rockumentary.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As gripping and as smart a piece of entertainment as you'll find this year.
As the title might suggest, it's shot through with a melancholy lyricism and evanescent twilight splendour.
Easily one of the films of the year.
This is a film about power, and its merciless abuse by men like the Commandant, told with muscular authority and fearless artistry.

As Macbeth, Fassbender -- consumed with power and guilt once he takes the throne -- is both terrifying and pitiful, a study of murderous resolve and inner disintegration. Cotillard is just as compelling.

Is By the Sea a bad film? Sometimes. But it has a wayward, abrasive emotional honesty that is ample compensation, and I'll take that over the more accomplished yet strenuously bland Pitt or Jolie vehicles I've seen in the past.
A melancholy minor masterpiece of dreamy originality, Inside Out is among Pixar's finest.
Quietly commanding, this is the best Italian crime film since Gomorrah.
Fascinating account of Weiwei's practice and politics that gives centre stage to his charismatic personality.
It subverts all the horror clichés while forging them anew to create an experience at once smartly ironic and terrifyingly immediate.
You have to endure 70-plus minutes before witnessing its low point: sneering footage of real 'Twilight' fans.
The results are slight but old-fashioned fun, Think less TS Eliot, more 'Carry On'.
Despite the occasional fun the movie has with psychoanalysis, there's something self-absorbed about its indulgent view of its characters' neuroses.
It's quite cheering to encounter such narrative complexity in a mainstream movie.
A touching coming-of-age story set against the violence and poverty of Rio's favelas.
Disappointingly tepid and flavourless fare.
Structurally, the film is a mess: on screen, the novel's digressive, anecdotal narrative seems directionless and muddled.
A hugely entertaining romp. But Hail, Caesar! also emerges as a smart and subtly unnerving exploration of the seductive appeal of films over its paying audience - over us.
Lady Macbeth is a deftly assured cinematic debut from theatre director William Oldroyd: a film of unnerving, accumulating tension, punctuated by moments of violence that leave you reeling.
It has a haunting, desolate beauty, and it's achingly sad, like a half deserted zoo in the middle of a Midwestern winter.
A remarkable stylistic achievement, then, but Loving Vincent has its flaws, and I can't say that its script is equal to the triumphant visual technique on display.
The Reagan Show will offer a peculiarly potent hit of nostalgia and cultural cringe.
It's Mel Brooks at his most daft and puerile: sophisticated and silly, a black-and-white art film with schlong jokes.
[Shia] LaBeouf is great value as McEnroe in his hair-trigger mood.
... The Graduation is fascinating, gripping even.
he fact Belle de Jour resists such settled interpretation is one reason to see it... Another reason is Deneuve.

A film delicately attuned to rural life in all its lyrical and sublime glories, with special credit to cinematographer Joshua James Richards for capturing the wild splendour of Yorkshire locations. Make no mistake: this is a determinedly unsentimental.
Beyond its (admittedly virtuoso) restaging of facts, Detroit falls short, a blunt instrument with little insight into the systemic causes behind the racism.

It's a strenuously well-meaning, often chewy, sometimes stilted drama about a plummy London barrister's attempt to expose the criminals blackmailing a young gay man with whom he had a brief 'association'.
. . .a sumptuous study in atmosphere that lulls you into a hypnotic trance; a gently profound essay on time and its human limits.
This elegant, elliptical mood piece is an impressively original work, compelling proof that Escalante is one of Mexico's finest young directors.
The lovely thing about England Is Mine is that it mostly eschews cliches.
This is a cheerfully superficial film that orchestrates effective, and sometimes surprisingly nasty, thrills with unpretentious efficiency.
As if you'd want it any other way, Lynch retains that sense of enigma, of velvety mystery that runs through his best work.

Some scenes carry the innocent charm of a Disney film. Others have a dark intensity that might trouble the most seasoned viewers. This isn't just a challenge to conventional marketing but an affront -- and all the better for it.
But this is still a wildly promising first feature from [Rungano] Nyoni, and marks her as a filmmaker to watch.
... the result is an up-close, surprisingly unguarded portrait of a compelling artist.
Colin Farrell's heart surgeon faces a nightmarish ultimatum, making Yorgos Lanthimos' latest one of this year's most bold and interesting films.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to resist this understated, delicate, winningly eccentric movie.
Catnip for cinephiles.
You Were Never Really Here is brilliantly made, daringly structured and invested with jumpy, lurid lyricism. But this stylistic triumph fails to resonate emotionally.
Marina battles on, a force of nature, despite the elements gathered in opposition, and this big-hearted, sweepingly realised melodrama plays like an intoxicating tribute to that fighting spirit.
Dark River is a bracing reminder of Barnard's talent, but enter its depths with caution.
The results borrow freely from French New Wave, American teen drama, and more - but the great triumph of Lady Bird is that it remains in Gerwig's voice: it's fresh, funny, and lastingly poignant.
Loveless is brilliantly accomplished and yet I found its unsparing pessimism hard going.
But Last Flag Flying disappoints. By comparison to The Last Detail, it's bland and underpowered, with a script that lacks the earlier movie's poetry or razory wit. And on its own terms it struggles.
Watching it today I can appreciate the historical significance of The Graduate, and Mike Nichols' direction is sharp and stylish. Yet I'm ambivalent about the film.
The Final Year... is a kind of disaster movie, the chronicle of an impending catastrophe that creeps up on its victims.
A breathtaking performance by Zhao Tao.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An elliptic, bracingly experimental feature told mostly in Gaelic.
From the makers of Sherpa, this visually breathtaking documentary features vertigo-inducing shots of climbers scaling various high-altitude summits, accompanied by a soaring orchestral score.
[Salim] Shaheen is a force of nature, and a true cinematic maverick, and the documentary is a hoot.
It is sombre and (to risk a rather pompous word) necessary viewing.

As with so many portraits of family dysfunction there's a sense of unease here, one that Haneke amplifies brilliantly. It is a collection of disquieting fragments, discordant snapshots that create a mood of unsettling menace, of impending catastrophe.
It's a sly and vivid dispatch from the struggling margins of Trump's America. And it's Robert Pattinson on peak form, giving a performance of desperate ferocity and trapped intensity.
Sometimes you have the feeling you're watching a solid Netflix TV drama, an impression underscored by the film's ramblingly episodic structure.

This sensitive, not entirely uncritical, documentary grows ever more poignant as you realise Houston was never able to find a satisfactory answer to that question [in the title], not least for herself.
There are shades of Hitchcock, notably Rebecca and Notorious. But this is a film to savour not for its narrative twists but its air of thickening psychological complexity.

[It] catches you unawares: seemingly so slight, a chamber piece in a minor key, it is in fact as honest and complex a depiction of family life -- and the fraught, tender, melancholy relationship between generations -- that I've seen in a long time.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The barrelling fun and fizzy invention of the film-making is unstoppable. Calling last orders on a great trilogy, this is one of the most entertaining British films of the year, so far.

Skyfall has fun playing with Bond's image, but the producers are wary of being too revisionistic. In fact, the film is good because it's such a stirring affirmation of the things 007 films have always done well.
This is a bloated splurge of special effects and gamey acting -- to say it's no worse than last month's Spider-Man film is to point up the lacklustre year it's been so far for blockbusters.
It's a brilliantly accomplished hostage drama -- claustrophobic and breathlessly paced -- and Greengrass' commanding piloting of a Hollywood juggernaut can blind you to the film's faults.
Is anyone else in America making films like Lee Daniels? For my money, he deserves his name above the title.
It is exhilarating film-making, engineered with dizzying invention, and it combines commanding 3D digital effects -- some of the best I've ever seen -- with a surprisingly soulful touch.
Blue is the Warmest Colour is a wonderful film: tender, raw, honest, sad and performed with intensity.
Versus is a smart, respectful portrait of a towering film-maker.
movie_title: Versus: The Life and Films of Ken Loach (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's a brash, wayward vigour about this film, and it features one of Hanks' best performances in a long time.
This is all pleasantly watchable but it keeps the stakes low, and the mood of subdued sentimentality doesn't feel entirely appropriate for the often bleak crises that are inflicted on Wilson.
Green Room is a nasty, cold-hearted, claustrophobic film with moments of gratuitous violence and sick comedy. I liked it much more than Almost Famous.
Intermittently amusing.
movie_title: Razzle Dazzle: A Journey Into Dance (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While I hesitate to attach anything so worthy as a message to a film as light and airy as this, its celebration of life, in all its odd, kinked, flawed variations, is winningly affirmative.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is an admiring portrait of the city but it's also tinged with sadness.
All credit to the actors for sustaining this intensity for more than two hours, especially Costa who, by the end of the film, gives a turn of raw, snotty intensity.
The animation is zippy and crammed with smart sight gags.
At a time when so many European films play it safe and small, Tale of Tales is an improbable folly, with an eccentric grandeur to be cherished.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Made with the rigour of the best journalism and haunting emotional artistry, Fire at Sea deserves to be seen as widely as possible.
The smoke-and-mirrors storyline is either too obvious in the way it anticipates surprise developments or too absurd for us to care. It gallivants all over the place, too.
It is the latest film from Aki Kaurismäki, and fans will be glad to know he's doing what he does best: lugubrious, parched-dry deadpan, pitched with deceptive economy and masterly minimalism.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's watchable enough though, and Hathaway is terrific. Forget that rampaging CGI giant -- her performance is the film's most special effect.
A haunting, quietly affecting documentary.

Emerging from the well-chosen clips, Jacobs and Moses seem like opposites, but the film prefers to imply rather than dwell on any great differences. At its absorbing heart are conflicting ideas of how urban life should be organised.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film of masterly artistry, heaving political anger and uncontained ambition.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: No joke, Toni Erdmann is an extraordinary piece of cinema.
There is mordant humour here, rippled with moments of extraordinary tenderness, but at heart this is a grave, unconsoling and profoundly sad film.
It's a visually stunning portrait of a modern-day inferno. It's also a frankly depressing chronicle of the toxic legacy of industrial mining.

Essentially, the film is concerned with a deeper mystery: how to deal with the aftermath of a grief like Anna's; and director Ozon tackles this concern with subtlety, intelligence and affecting sensitivity.

If the first half of the film sees the director on familiar territory, going around in circles like a dog chasing his tail, with these final two miniatures of disquieting pessimism and piercing melancholy he recovers his bite, and some.
A startlingly intimate portrait of a remarkable woman.

movie_review_blurb: There are some good ideas, but I was disappointed not to get an ending that pieced everything together into a satisfying chain of events. The film provokes questions, all right, but too many are left unanswered.
movie_title: Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The whole concept founders on McConaughey's unalterable cheesiness. Flimsy though it is, the film has a couple of okay jokes, and might have been passable with a more endearing star.
The film's wacky ghoulishness holds your attention, but there's not much more than that on offer. Despite a lot of manic effort, none of the actors makes an impression.
movie_title: Funuke Domo, Kanashimi no ai Wo Misero (Funuke Show Some Love, You Losers!) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The story's main elements are the stuff of broadbrush, bittersweet television drama.
The film is a flavourful record of what is - as the interviewees are well aware - a vanishing culture, but it doesn't dig deep.

It's not a film of any great pungency. In the title role, Rupert Friend is perhaps even more callow than the part requires, and the wry narration, read by Frears, is wrongly pitched. The main drawback, however, is the not terribly exciting source material
The film is decidedly low-key. As such movies go, it's enjoyable, though you might find yourself wishing Mikey would just pull himself together.
Strikingly shot though it is, this Hungarian film, by Kornel Mundruczo, is sunk by a drama that represents art-house cinema at its worst: a dull, gloomy tale that skirts questions of plausibility.

There have been countless films about ordinary, lonely people finding love, but few of them can have had characters quite as unassertive and nondescript as the couple featured in this Mexican comic drama.

The only viewers on whom the film is likely to make a big impression are young fans of Robert Pattinson, the heart-throb star of Twilight. For them, watching their idol's unrestrained performance as Dali will be quite a crash course in surrealism.
What you make of Hamer's brand of quirkiness is very much a matter of taste. My experience was that the film was often on the brink of annoying me, yet never did.
There is barely an out and-out gag - and certainly none that's funny - in the whole two hours of deliberately bad acting.
The director, Jackie Oudney, gives Bonneville and Duff's scenes a proper romcom glow, but Aschlin Ditta's script resorts to a lot of faffing about to postpone the inevitable happy ending.
All of this, however, is plainly just a veneer on a solidly generic punch-up movie, and it thus becomes a drag. A more cartoonish approach would probably have been more fun.

At its worst, in some of its improvised rambles, it demonstrates the value of a well-thought-out screenplay. At its exhilarating and poignant best, it proves that a film can play all sorts of postmodern games yet still touch its viewers' emotions.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Jon Wright's film delivers its shocks as efficiently as the average American equivalent. Its British jokiness makes it less scary than it perhaps could have been, but it gains more from this trade-off than it loses.
Fruitful themes and patterns emerge -- in, for instance, the way it intertwines Johnson's family life and the arduous scenes she witnesses during her work
The 3-D effect been applied. It adds a bit of extra fun to what is otherwise a routine repeat of the formula.
A return to the frantic style of 2014's The Lego Movie, it may lack wild inspiration, but its rat-a-tat-tat jokes are consistently worth a smile.
The scares begin promisingly, but tail off when everything is out in the open.
For all its boisterousness, it takes far too long to get to the action.
You may well prefer the David Attenborough approach, but the footage is still wonderful.
Opinions will differ about the tact level of certain scenes, but overall this love story is valuable and touching.
Maggie Mulubwa is captivating as the girl, and the story is an intriguing mixture of satire and tragedy, but the film's carefully artistic style (though an achievement) is at times too distracting.
Parents, if your children aren't champing at the bit to see this one, don't bother.

Daniel Radcliffe is on good form in this dramatisation of Yossi Ghinsberg's memoir... but Greg McLean's film fails in an area where true-story movies should really be looking to pick up points: realism.
Taken on its own terms, the movie is so enjoyable that niggles can easily be set aside. Above all, it's rich in good performances.

Vaughn's honourable, shaven-headed hulk is introduced in a strong, Michael Mann-style crime story that gives us an interest in his fate. Thus drawn in, I felt the skull-smashing gore of the final scenes only cheapened the film.
It's colourful and well appointed but essentially period fluff.

The film slips in and out of its heroine's freaky perceptions, allowing sudden surprises amid placid Nordic interiors, and Harboe's tender turn gives us a character we can feel for. At heart, though, it has nothing super-scary, nor mind-boggling.
The new film is every bit as bright, funny and cosy as its predecessor.
The film doesn't have enough layers to justify its length. It masks the fact that it comes from a play, but only by conforming to a bland type of arty indie cinema.
What unfolds is an adequate answer to Marvel's first Avengers film.
In an account full of eye-opening scenes, the film gives us a knotty, balanced idea of the moral quandaries involved.
Its desire to address big American themes is well realised in the main plot, which credibly sets up a friendship between two war veterans.
It's essentially a weepie, and as such it's a winner: nicely acted, fairly restrained in its emotionalism and bringing us a curious true story.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Clooney may not be a weighty sociocultural dramatist, but he's not dim, so it's surprising to see how misjudged and tokenistic this secondary part of the film turns out to be.
On balance, the attention to style does the trick: the movie is rewarding in its own way.
The film's own artistic principles don't seem too fascinating, but it's an intriguing concoction.
It's reasonably lively, and not impious (if you ask me), but set against the best cartoons, it's not the greatest story ever told.
It's an unwieldy concept -- an English literature lesson in pageant form -- but the results are at least colourful and perky.
At the heart of this film by Emily Harris and Ate de Jong is a credible, intimate portrait of two people deeply in love but unsure where they're going.
Set in Norway, but speaking English, it never finds a rhythm as it proceeds through assorted nasty murders, while Hole remains boringly stymied.
The early stuff is nothing we haven't seen before in similar films, but Asensio's performance makes it absorbing.

I found it largely arid and a waste of its impressive cast (including Kristin Scott Thomas, Timothy Spall, Bruno Ganz and Patricia Clarkson). Its situations are laboured and much of its dialogue is unwieldy.
It's touching to see the affection this Mr and Mrs Chips have for their pupils.
There's a lot of quickfire banter without anyone actually saying anything funny.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It may be heavily contrived, but it's a suitably punchy ending for a vigorous, unruly film that seems honest in its depiction of living with disabilities.

South Korean action movies often marry amazing fight scenes to barking-mad plots. This example, directed by Jung Byung-gil, reaches spectacular heights in its violent combats, yet it keeps deflating itself with its story's conceits.
Simply as a wallow in black-and-white Gallic romanticism, it's a treat, but Tavernier also provides good stuff in his commentary.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You can no doubt learn something about the Chinese way of death from this documentary set in a rather tacky-looking funeral home in the People's Republic, but what Carol Salter's film is most emphatically about is youthful life.
If you're no expert on Lebanon, the film's contemplations are all the more educational.
The film's cultural distinctiveness helps a bit... set off by winning performances and all-round vitality.
The movie can't go too wrong with its sultry ambiance and the recollections of its two troupers.
Ildiko Enyedi's film becomes an eccentric reverie on the forces of attraction and the countervailing hassles that can keep people apart.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There's presumably a degree of autobiography in all of this on El Said's part, so he might have done better to make a personal documentary.. the results may still have been pretentious, they might also have had a directness lacking in this hollow drama.
movie_title: In the Last Days of the City (Akher ayam el madina) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There's not much drama, but I was amused, engaged and touched by the goings-on at the Christchurch Poultry, Bantam and Pigeon Club.
Tverdovsky doesn't take the story anywhere really startling. His compassionate, intriguing film is enjoyable but anticlimactic.
The film's cinematic flair is occasionally increased through high drama and surrealism; the ending is too much, but before it there's an excellent flourish.

Peter Mackie Burns's drama is credible, delivered in a style that fully captures the feel of her world, but its story's brief time span -- a matter of days -- leaves us unsure of how much is at stake.
It's honourable escapism, but hardly inspired.
It's a clunky espionage thriller crossed with Downton period drama.
Koolhoven would have dealt more honestly with us if he had made the film a short, brazenly pulpy thriller, instead of the ponderous, pretentious melodrama it is.

This doesn't shake up the usual practices of Winterbottom films - in that context, the casual style is thoroughly familiar - but it does yield a movie that might appeal to lovers of the rock ethos in general.
Certain moments, however, do achieve that spellbinding kind of strangeness, and there are also points where Rodrigues's seriousness of purpose is clear and powerful.
It's a film of innocent hokum, played with heroic conviction by its stars. Towards the end, though, you can only giggle as all that mountainous snow gives way to slush.

The fact that Ronald Reagan's administration was big on PR and presentation is hardly news, and, though this documentary made up of television footage from the period claims to focus on that aspect of the presidency, it doesn't dig deep.
Here the soapiness is much nearer the surface.
It's a good-hearted film that at times plays like the work of a Kiwi Wes Anderson. Its storyline is tritely calculated, but the surface details are appealing.
Its high-energy exploits should go down well enough with the younger end of Lego's cinema audience, but its story is formulaic and its jokes (apart from a brilliant feline cameo) spring no surprises.
At its best, the story is an adequate yarn; at its dullest, it's a lifeless rehash of The Wolf of Wall Street, without even the sex and drugs.
It's a good-looking film, and Rupert Everett reads nicely from Beaton's diaries, but we get no fresh insights.
Weinstein's quiet study of Hasidic society is part of the film's appeal, but the story's crux would have potential in any context.

It's a slightly stiff routine -- he (Suggs) doesn't have the knack of making scripted lines sound unscripted -- but it's likeable, and some of the anecdotes are reminders of just how many ardent fans Madness have.
It's well resourced. It doesn't, however, have anything to take it to a higher plane.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For viewers interested in West Wing life, it's a tasty behind-the-scenes tour, and for those averse to liberals, it has the comedy of this lot being hit by Trump's election win.
Though the special-effects spectacles are fine, and a few scenes even have a sense of wonder and magic, there's nothing distinctive about the movie.
No great dramatic surprises occur, but the film is a subtle, civilised offering for those who like this sort of thing.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Action movies aren't always meant to be credible, but here the nonsense level is too destabilising.
Bryan Cranston, Laurence Fishburne and Steve Carell are easy to watch, but the drama is never deeply convincing.
If you've waited keenly through the two-and-a-bit years since the second film, you're likely to find the final chapter rewarding enough.
The debating sessions are hard slogs, but elsewhere the film's style is engaging.
movie_title: The Nothing Factory (A Fábrica de Nada) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is one for fans of simple, optimistic war movies, but that doesn't mean they will think much of its colourless characters and monotonous action scenes.
As well as being sure to remind you how fortunate you are, Emmanuel Gras's film is beautiful and poetic, something it achieves without condescension.

Still, the play is a solid thing, significant for being one of the original texts in the literature devoted to the war; and it couldn't be filmed much better than it is in Saul Dibb's adaptation, a well-judged movie with an excellent cast.
How disappointing that the film descends into hamminess and overused jump scares.
Lord alone knows why the plot's weaker bits had to be quite so sluggish, or why the leading cop, played by Gerard Butler, had to be a charmless meathead.
A drama-cum-thriller about a woman trying to save her sister from a nightmare marriage, it overstuffs its plot and overdoes its melodrama.
It's the general mediocrity -- plastic-looking characters, clichéd jokes -- that should deter you.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film may not be an essential retelling of its well-known saga, but it adds a few striking illustrations.

There are moments of vagueness when you wish more effort had been made on the nuts-and-bolts stuff. Still, we get a strong sense of Curry's personality -- a sensitive perfectionist -- and there is ample footage of his great routines.
This worthwhile project is aided by a tough performance from Ruth Wilson in the lead role.
Actors and viewers alike are let down by a script that does everything by rote.

With this sci-fi concept, the writer/director Daniel Fitzsimmons means to say something about the human condition, but the fact his characters aren't human makes the story too arbitrary to have pathos.

I sometimes felt more like I was watching the pilot episode of a 1980s TV show -- a cheap action-adventure series in which the cheerful kung-fu teacher Bruce Lee would come to the aid of someone pestered by bad guys.
No Country for Old Men is a great return to form for the Coens. Even if you've never been a big fan of theirs, it's a film you should see if you like a good thriller.
The movie's all-round realism -- bolstered as it is by Judith Chemla's excellent lead performance and Stéphane Brizé's intimate direction -- is deeply absorbing.
Ai's long series of desolate vistas is more exhausting than seems necessary. Still, there's much to be said for a film that gives such a strong sense of how vast the refugee problem is.
Its heroes' macho joshing is dumb enough to make The A-Team sound like the Algonquin Round Table.

Kristina Grozeva and Petar Valchanov's Glory, from Bulgaria, is a watchable but pretty obvious satire about a railway worker who briefly becomes a celebrity in a stunt contrived by a cynical government PR woman.
Once everything's been unwrapped, Chris Peckover's film isn't the greatest movie anyone could wish for, but it's bright and vicious enough to please the audience to which it's proffered.

In its own way, it's a movie with plenty of imagination, but the gory progress from fight to fight to fight is monotonous, and the running time is quite demanding for those of us stuck with finite lifespans.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Eventually, its attitude becomes more indulgent, and we're faced with one of those irritating indies that go easy on manchild whimsicality.
Richard Gere, Rebecca Hall, Steve Coogan and Laura Linney collectively fail to rescue this trying-too-hard drama.
It employs the usual kids' animation formulas, but does so in style.
I don't mind that it's all improbable, but it's also quite dull.
Sonia Kronlund's film about him not only captures a portrait of a marvellous striver, but gives us glimpses of Afghan society.
Daniel Rezende's film is a little trite in its storyline, but its lusty, Scorsese-style picture of bad behaviour in the world of children's television is a circus show worth seeing.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This social drama is realistic and absorbing, but then Jia again leaps through time.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The visual content is impressive, with lots of spectacular shots of mountains, and of people doing risky things while going up and down.
Gary Sinyor's film has a basic but effective way of jangling its viewers' nerves at selected moments. One thing the visual trickery can't blot out, though, is the plot's unhelpful daftness.
For Almodovar fans, this will be a sumptuous return to the reds and pinks of his cinema.
Alexandre Aja's film has several flaws, but at least it's pleasantly odd.
The result is a mediocre showdown with a guessable twist.
The film does have one thing to give it pizzazz, and that's visual zest.
Special effects improve, but the sentiments in middling action movies for children remain the same. Still, this one is fairly lively.
This pair's adventure, which is equal parts gunplay and magic, is a bit dull at heart, but the well-imagined setting livens things up.
A comic franchise that has stayed loosely in tune with reality now goes screeching off into nonsense, with no good jokes to show for it.

Whether the film's ambiguous meanings strike you as profound or overblown, there's greatness enough in its aesthetic marvels: the power of its performances, the beauty of its images and the deftness of its sudden shifts.

(The) casting, and the skilled performances it brings us, are sufficient reasons to find the movie heartening, but the script is also of value. Although fairly rough-hewn, it has subtle touches and it campaigns on a noteworthy topic.
Fans of westerns will be happy enough here -- with an eventful story and lots of handsome landscapes -- but they'll know they aren't watching a classic.
It's rather laborious, but vivid enough to be worth a look if it's your kind of thing -- as it might be if you like Werner Herzog, Alejandro Jodorowsky or Guy Maddin.
Given wide latitude by the hero's gift, the story floats waywardly all over the place and, though the fancy camera moves are impressive, the journey is unsatisfying.
The insipid results give little insight into Buddhist thinking, but we see a few things we may want to remember in our own moments of vague contemplation.
The intensity of the subjects they address offsets the histrionic tendencies in the film's execution. There's no such defence, though, for the soapy subplots.

Though one of the new cast members -- John Lithgow as Ferrell's soft-hearted father -- is a big asset, severe damage is done by another: Mel Gibson as Wahlberg's macho dad. His grimacing performance as a sexist pig deadens every joke it touches.
Presented without any commentary, the film leaves you with a few questions, but as a high-emotion reality show, it's compelling.
The film's skilfully engineered intensity isn't for the squeamish.

This DreamWorks cartoon about a baby visualised as a suit-wearing executive big shot has bright ideas and slick bits of action, but the more I think about what its concept offers children, the more doubtful I am.
Its well-meant sympathy for unhappy outsiders isn't enough to hold together the scrappy farcical scenes.
Unmistakably ancient, but full of invention.
A few of the discussions are quite knotty, but the whole thing is still too steeped in American mawkishness to have a chance with anyone unpersuaded by that form of worship.

Wilson, who delivers overdone sarcasm in a slightly Fozzie Bear voice, is a well-imagined creation. His place in the film's plot, however, is generic: he's a grouch warmed up by the discovery that he has a teenage daughter.
There is basic tension, but the ending is a flop.
Richard Gere's performance in Joseph Cedar's drama brings to life a proud but desperate man scrambling to save face.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The 2012 film that revived 21 Jump Street was a funny action comedy that showed a reasonable amount of respect for the original television series. By this reckoning, Dax Shepard's CHIPS is a double failure.

Bruno Dumont's latest is set in 1910 and gives us a belle époque mixture of nonsense comedy and deeper weirdness. On the former score, it's fairly excruciating... In the artier moments, however, there are startling flourishes.
It's consistent with the duller examples of Hollywood's animated output.
When it comes to telling us who Whitney really was, however, the film only goes so far. [Although] for sure, it's absorbing.
Claire Ferguson's movie is not only powerful, but usefully varied in its range of tales.
Like all previous films about this line of work, it describes the mix of heroism and selfish thrill-seeking that leads people into the job.
movie_title: A Good Day to Die, Hoka Hey (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The characters' behaviour rings true, the tension is strong and the oily darkness of it all looks good. Within his vaguely realistic constraints, however, Shults doesn't find a way to nudge the story to a satisfying ending.
Austin is Malick's adopted home town, but if he really wanted to boost its profile, he would have been better off making a nice, simple documentary about it.
These tweaks are enough to make Jon Watts's film sufficiently different from past Spider-movies; and its tight story, funny jokes and cute characters are enough to make it pretty enjoyable.
It is a credit to this biopic that its leading man, Demetrius Shipp Jr, is an adequate double for the rapper and actor Tupac Shakur. Beyond that, there's little to be said for Benny Boom's film.
The characters' behaviour rings true, the tension is strong and the oily darkness of it all looks good.
The bittersweet contrivances in Martin Provost's storytelling are blatant, but the covering veneer of realism is attractive.
Lassgard huffs and puffs well, but the script (by the film's director, Hannes Holm) lays out its simple story with increasing heavy-handedness, and the humour is perhaps too Swedish to work here.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When Steve James's documentary suggests that Abacus was the victim of a concerted Establishment plot... it doesn't have quite enough evidence for a conviction, but it is an absorbing study of the court case, the bank and Chinatown itself.
Not only for cat people, then, but you need to be that way inclined if you are to be entranced by all of the many shots that just show cats being cats.
Nacho Vigalondo's film begins as a seemingly realistic drama, then suddenly gains a big streak of fantasy.
Golf buffs might appreciate its recreation of the sport in the late 19th century, but to love the film unreservedly, you'll need an appetite for the cinematic equivalent of treacle-topped porridge.
Rahul Jain finds colourful sights, and he composes his images like a latter-day Degas. Even though this approach has a kind of beauty, viewers can't fail to see how hellish conditions are.
[An] informative biographical piece.
This biopic, starring Michael Keaton as Kroc, can't reverse that outcome, of course, but it does let Mac and Dick seize something from their conqueror.
In this case, however, the honest, straight-up public servant [Wahlberg] plays is kind of a fake.
The climax is almost as crass as the beginning.

Bellocchio's wearying analysis of mother love is the least compelling mark of the film's nationality. More rewarding is his use of a recognisably Italian cinematic style, one involving visual richness and melancholy explorations of urban society.
Based on Colm Toibin's novel, and starring Saoirse Ronan as an Irish immigrant in 1950s New York, this genial drama about leaving home welcomes you in.
The latest cartoon from Disney is a hectic adventure movie for action-lovers. See review, in this section.
The film has a bruising sort of panache, so it meets the basic requirements of its genre.
This Hollywood clunker, in which Charlie Day and Ice Cube play teachers who come to blows, simply isn't funny.
Lovers of old kitsch movies will appreciate this pastiche, an arch tale of a suburban witch.

A film of two halves, then, and though I'm not convinced it all fits together perfectly, the latter part's move into all-out horror is entertaining in itself.
Kleber Mendonca Filho's film takes a storyline that could have been nothing but soap suds and bolsters it with realism, compassion and a well-conveyed sense of time's passing.
The Lost City of Z is a finely drawn period piece that suffers from its less than heroic central character.

There's a second-hand feel to his state-of-the-nation look at civic corruption, and to the plot's moments of ominous mystery, which recall Michael Haneke. That the film remains strong and involving is largely due to its core subject.
Pablo Larrain's ingenious, debonair biopic uses a blend of fact and fiction to celebrate the poet Pablo Neruda and the power of literature.
Terence Davies is British cinema's great chronicler of subdued, pent-up existences.

Assembling interview footage of James Baldwin and readings from his works, the documentary I Am Not Your Negro is a potent study of the writer, the 1960s civil-rights movement and the continuing struggles of African-Americans.

David Tennant [plays the role] with conviction and a nice Glaswegian drawl, but the film is a dodgy business that makes things up -- including a pregnant girlfriend (Elisabeth Moss) -- for no good reason.

Whatever you make of the counterculture sentimentalism in the film's story of a rebellious mental patient, [Nicholson's] performance is superb, a showcase both for his wolfish glints and for his more subtle abilities.
movie_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Luxuriously strange.
A poignant movie with a much calmer idea of happiness than the average sports movie.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A tender and extremely graceful piece of work.
It's a good film for lovers of New York, but even they might find monotony in its reliance on library footage of street scenes.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: François Ozon's film is inspired by the 1932 picture Broken Lullaby, and, though the ever-inventive director has taken the plot in a new direction the movie's appeal is essentially that of an old-fashioned melodrama.

Brendan Gleeson and Emma Thompson are fine, and the story has inherent strength, but you never feel you've been transported to wartime Germany, and that loss robs the film of the tense, sickening atmosphere it needs.
Dreamy and enigmatic in the American-indie way.
It's been a while since we saw a crime thriller with such a healthy chance of making viewers smile.
This is dramatised vividly with the help of a sound performance by Pekka Strang, but there's a touch of typical biopic plodding, and not much context.
There are telling and touching moments, but we've come to see, over the years, that it's quite easy to find an involving story in any formal set of challenges imposed on young people.

Directed by Hideaki Anno and Shinji Higuchi, it has an excellent Godzilla, whose rampages are a good mixture of modern and traditional-looking special effects. Often, though, the monster is out of the action.
Despite her best sardonic smouldering and an extensive designer wardrobe, Theron can't make anything compelling of her character, an empty vessel in a spy story that delivers low-IQ le Carré.
In short, I enjoyed a beguiling bittersweet wallow.
Its staid narrative is so monotonous, however, that even the shots of undersea life become a little dull: it's all just one fin after another.
Thanks to his membership of the international political jet set, this fly-on-the-wall stuff has moments of interest, but the portrait is far too reverent to be substantial journalism.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This weirdness, played straight, is hard to interpret, particularly at the moments when pleasure turns to pain, but there's enough in the story to give the film a bit of dramatic potency, complementing its sheer oddity value.

With Geoffrey Rush as his star, Stanley Tucci (writing and directing) is able to capture a good likeness of Alberto Giacometti in this biopic... The artist's messy studio is a fine sight, too, and fans of cultured chit-chat will not mind lingering there.
I'm not sure how many Americans will ever see this movie, but the more the better.
Patrick Hughes's movie is still throwaway tosh, but if I come across it on television one day, I might watch for a while.
Twenty years after he directed the monumental Con Air, Simon West does duty on one of those embarrassing underpowered British attempts at an American-style thriller.
It's an energetic but unsurprising film, with Flemyng's most obvious contribution being his gathering of an above-par cast that includes old colleagues such as Charlie Cox and Dexter Fletcher.
The director, Philip John, knows how to stage a passionate scene and add fuzzy indie folk music, but the storytelling that sets up these moments is horribly mimsy.
The film's environment, with its mix of toughness and beauty, is a good match for the simple but robust love story.
Licensed by this grounding in Victorian show business, the film is itself a lurid crowd-pleaser, complete with nasty violence, an extravagant plot and a valiant Scotland Yard inspector (Bill Nighy).
Made under the BBC's Storyville banner, it's bound to appear on TV before long, but those who enjoy marvelling at the solar system's planets may prefer a cinema screening.
It's not a hopeless idea, but the film makes a hash of it. In aiming for stylish gore and a clever plot twist, it writes cheques its clumsy storytelling skills can't cash.

It has its hero confront the challenges of being over the hill -- an awkward theme for a movie that itself comes across as a weary, backward-looking project for Seann William Scott and the actor-director Jay Baruchel.
It's piquant, but has an air of being done by the book.
As panegyrics go, however, it's a creditable piece of work -- calm, attentive and varied.
movie_title: Dennis Skinner: Nature of the Beast (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This one... is particularly waffly, though when the cast stop talking, Sanders uses music and imagery to create resonant moods.
As in Annabelle, the scares derived from the creepy-faced doll are more fun than the stuff about nebulous demonic possession.
Ghoulish and tedious.

One flaw in Nicolaj Arcel's film is that it's too short and compressed to make anything lucid of its cockamamie mythology. At the same time, it's such a leaden piece of work that you wouldn't want it to be it any longer.
The domestic saga is of general interest, but the film is still chiefly for a car-loving audience.

movie_review_blurb: Happily Ever After is never as insightful or as funny as Woody at his best. But the film has a fine-tuned approach to human behavior.

Lithe, clever, thoughtful, well-acted and certainly entertaining.
Miscast yet marvelous, Paltrow and the rest of the cast hold you to the movie, even when you intuitively sense something is lacking.
Though Memory works perfectly well as a policier, it works even better as a character study of a man losing his edge.

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a bit betwixt and between -- whimsical but eerie, funny but melancholy. That said, Corpse Bride truly is like nothing else at the movies these days.

Like its protagonists, it means well, but gets mixed up. Too easily.
[Fiennes] gives an Oscar-worthy portrayal, holding us with his quivering half-smile and his wounded eyes.
Brimming with bright dialogue, complex characters and moments of sheer aching sweetness, it's Chekhov with a side of red-eye gravy.
A fractured fairy tale that's both too grim and not Grimm enough.
Richardson is the reason to see Asylum. A lot of what happens doesn't really make sense, yet her intensity hooks us.
[Barrymore's] radiant, sexy 'n' sweet manner provides a happy heart for this silly little love song of a movie.

movie_review_blurb: Move over, Michael Bay. The Island is no longer the loudest, dumbest movie of the summer.

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, we're won over by Beatrix's story. Hers was, as Richard Griffiths says of Thomas Hardy in The History Boys, 'a saddish life, but not an unappreciated one.' Even more appreciated now, thanks to this honest, unassuming little film.

The delicious trimmings...arrive early and stay late, filling nearly every minute...with a lighthearted glow, some impudent snickers, and a glorious dose of humankind's liberating ability to triumph over a Scrooge or two.

The Man From Elysian Fields is a cold, bliss-less work that groans along thinking itself some important comment on how life throws us some beguiling curves.

This year's spilled turkey tribute...provides an abundance of holiday stuffing/suffering in dispelling the dysfunctional family spirit.
... a spellbinding study of Andy Goldsworthy, a Scottish land-sculptor who creates location-specific work using only the organic vegetation and minerals found in his "studio."

...a jolly roger rollercoaster of fun.

It's the dumberest movie I've ever seen!

Mark Moskowitz ? has made a quaintly interesting, but too long (at 128 minutes), self-involved docu-mystery for the literary-minded.

Sure, some people are in it for the money. We're here for the fun! Go, watch The Italian Job, and on the way home pick up a six-pack of MINI Coopers. They'll fit in the closet
A striking, poignant, and seductive saga of a Jewish lesbian in love with the dallying wife of a Nazi officer and mother of four.
An odd, odd (did I say odd) portrait of a serial killer set against a backdrop that is plum smack in the middle of white bread, Ozzie and Harriet, America.
...a flatulent space bomb. There may not be air in outer space, but you can smell this one a galaxy away.
This hip blend of Sherlock Holmes and Howard Hughes is an offbeat suspense comedy.
...flat on substance, poor on relationships, big on predictability, and slow getting anywhere.
Brilliant. Mike Figgis has shown us the future of digital technology. It shall be glorious.

...just the right recipe to leave a smile on your face.

movie_review_blurb: It's a male-bonding road movie that veers off a weary course filled with dreary clichés on the way to a possible treasure in diamonds. The trip is barely worth it.
Overlong by a mile, this latest romantic non-thriller from director-actor Sydney Pollack is Hollywood's gift to cure insomnia.
Very enjoyable debut feature...Popper's camera captures the angst of the grassroots crusade in its massive slog for integrity on the campaign trail.
This is easily one of the funniest films of the year and in many a year. A laugh riot. Honest. Please, Mum, give me more!
Look for a crash landing as this airless, misbegotten movie sinks under the weight of a boggy, recycled tale of paths crossing on the proverbial wrong side of the tracks.
boring and predictable
Idle Hands is all thumbs. Ten of 'em, black and blue and bloodied, all pointed down in deference of the Siskel and Ebert rating system. Yuck.
A wildly entertaining sci-fi comedy, a perfect cup of interstellar action-adventure eggnog to compliment the serious Yuletide films.
A world-class winner [about] a perpetual dreamer stepping up to the plate in a poignant grand slam story of ambitions lost & gained among ethnic outcasts of 1956 Staten Island

It's as dull as a butter knife and slowed to interminable mediocrity, and inadvertently brings to mind the title of Marshall's autobiography: "Wake Me When It's Funny."
Here's one that should have stayed buried under a rock pile down at Fred and Barney's quarry.

movie_review_blurb: King Kong light. Insipid Joe Young. Just because this film is rated PG doesn't mean it has to be written on the level of an orangutan.
The Mod Squad is: 1. Sexy. 2. Cool. 3. Mod. 4. None of the above. 5. And then some!
cheap zirconium garbage

Angelou's pen remains mightier than her camerawork.
Childhood innocence, homo-erotic fantasies, and an endless flow of suck-em stand-in blow-pops all have their beguiling, unsettling moments.
It may not be as fresh as its predecessor, it still begs a look-see. As the year winds down, this is one fine holiday ham that should be savored, not skinned.
As noble an effort this is, released a week after Yom Kippur, the Jewish day of atonement, it will only receive second-class accommodations from the movie-going public.
Here's a delightfully screwball satire that's as enjoyable as your favorite ice cream on a hot summer day. Slick and smooth.
Two broken thumbs up.
The South China Sea's answer to the Bermuda Triangle, but off-the-shelf acting and a hackneyed plot won't keep this oversized barge afloat.
What Dreams May Come? If I were a betting man, I'd say none. Zilch. Nada. Bleech.
a spiffy-looking but empty-headed update
If you were Noah, you'd probably want to sink the ark before you'd care to spend time wading through this waterlogged effort.
A marvelous pastiche of a legendary sports hero, a compelling and fascinating tribute to one of baseball's great figures, in size (six feet four) and accomplishment.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg (2000)

movie_review_blurb: For all the money ($80 million) spent on this early mid-year entry, all you, the viewer, get is Dull Impact.
Scenes evaporate before your very eyes. Bad puns roll off the heroes and anti-hero's tongues and lay dead before your feet.
If karaoke were an Olympic sport, this American entry would finish out of the medal round. Way out.

Equal doses of fairy tale with quixotic overtones, romantic treacle, and subtle sci-fi, this small British-Spanish import looks (marginally) better on paper than on screen.
movie_title: The Man with Rain in His Shoes (Twice Upon a Yesterday) (1998)

movie_review_blurb: This one's a winner.
...a grand visual delight and liberating sixteenth century costume tale.

a turgid, never-say-die, and--despite its pretentious homage to Hitchcock and King--occasionally scary vehicle
Kim Basinger has selected an honest attempt to demarcate actress-defining moments. Unfortunately, she has chosen...poorly.

Bring It On is a forgettable, hackneyed effort -- a presumptuous, feel-good movie that is a bubble-headed mess.
This big-screen adaptation of the 1971 cult classic is a sure candidate for many worst ten film lists.

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent to experimental light aircraft, this is a bumpy ride that sputters and fails, not quite crashing yet never soaring above its earnest intentions.
The Harmonists reveals for you that life is full of joy and pain. Here's a show you shouldn't miss.
Wacky, wild, side-splitting, and refreshing as all hell. And then some.
Every Thanksgiving we often over-indulge and This Is My Father feels somewhat bloated after telling an over-long sentimental ballad of love gained and lost.
Producer Deborah Oppenheimer's journey of discovery about her late mother's past appears legitimately destined for award consideration.
movie_title: Into The Arms Of Strangers: Stories Of The Kindertransport (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Here is a provocative and profound film that deserves your undivided attention. Don't change the channel.
Without the sarcastic wit of television mega-talent of David E. ("Emmy") Kelley, this lowbrow horror entry might have been titled Lake Flaccid.
Daring in concept and inspirational for young and old alike, this is truly a near rapturous adventure -- a unique audience pleaser.
Long live Chucky!
No gutter humor here, just a veritable country-and-western serial murder comedy. Yeehaw!
Scientific fact: the universe is a big vacuum. Scientific corollary: Wing Commander sucks.
The latest magnum horror opus from the mixed-up mind of Tim Burton is an fx feast for the eyes, but leaves a hollow spot in the spiritual soul.
I suggest a detour around Forces of Nature until its arrival on home video.
...a simple and refreshing diversion.
Thematically-crippled. A half-hearted sultry gumshoe noir piece that will quickly fall by the wayside.
Among Giants' blah story of love among the high tension wires is a limp disappointment of voltages dashed.
Rush out and catch Rush Hour.
Off-kilter sweet and hopelessly romantic, with a dash of acne and a heaping of dark gray matter, is Rushmore, the new comedy from the director of 1996's offbeat Bottle Rocket.
Awkward pacing problems at the hands of a novice helmer, but the strong material and the fine delivery more than make up for the directorial inconsistencies.

movie_review_blurb: An angst-ridden one-act talkathon between an egregious fool, struggling actor, and exceedingly qualified cad-and his two separate, but equal, significant others.

...a lukewarm, lighthearted yet wry stab at office politics that will strike a responsive chord among many a 9-to-5er.
deliciously malevolent
Simon Birch's bark shrivels under the weight of its two-hour length and dramatically under-developed script.
John Waters' Pecker (conjure up the image!) is a limp effort in search of a Viagra fix. Too bad the main character's name isn't Cigar.
A wintry, truth-based, Charlyesque tale of star-crossed lovers about the titular sense lost, regained, and then lost again, i.e., double-negative-nonsense.
Julia Sweeney fashions a small, poignant, survivalist gem that's simple in concept, entertaining in delivery, and big in heart.
A heartfelt, engaging, yet ultimately unfulfilling, effort to perpetuate the myth that was Andy Kaufman.
Anyone over ten would be better off watching re-runs of The Cleo Awards.
This is a more than mild laughter - on par with and what many viewers and critics will compare to last year's My Best Friend's Wedding
funny and edgy and absorbing
Step into the darkened theater and the familiar smell may not hit you immediately. Watch your step, though, because A Dog of Flanders is nothing but cinematic doggy poo.
Belgian director Frédéric Fonteyne's second feature is a short but ultimately tedious affair.
movie_title: Une liaison pornographique (An Affair of Love) (A Pornographic Affair) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Hey, you like 18-wheelers (Have you driven a big Ford lately?), country-and-western music, and an All-American meal (as in meat loaf), then here's a film for you.
I'm about forty years too old to take this movie seriously. Or even understand it.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Jackie Chan continues his late-blooming cinematic conquest of Hollywood with this oafish Wild West comedy, an often funny, formulaic, and sometimes bumbling, buddy movie.
On the day that one American goddess says goodbye to daytime television, an older, and seemingly now wiser, talk show hostess comes back to haunt us on the bigger screen.
Mulan is the latest Disney goldmine to hit thousands of screens and millions of Happy Meals.
When you're aiming for the tyke market, this 73-minute feature is more than able to keep the kids from squirming in their seats.
Art imitates life imitates art imitates life in this top-notch, straight-on adaptation about the "fictionalized" account of the 1992 presidential campaign.
There's nothing extraordinary about Metroland.
After such an exciting debut film and a lesser second effort, Edward Burns' third outing strikes out. That's it. Dudsville.
If you want a personal, compelling tale with a touch of intrigue, let Affliction haunt you for a couple of hours.
A rollicking good time filled with zesty swordplay, swashbuckling set pieces, spicy romance, and, heck, even a reasonably plausible storyline.
If you're looking for comedy nutrition here, you'll find yourself in stand-up anorexic hell.
Both a paean to lyric poetry and Hollywood's fondly remembered theatrically-set musical burlesques, LLL is quite audacious for its bubbly lightheadedness.
This is a adequately enjoyable date flick, a lesser semi-precious gem.

It's horrifying (and R-rated) if not utterly relentless; it sucks your breath away, perhaps too much.
Brestian (adj.) Bloated, boring, and long-winded, as in "Meet Joe Black is Brestian in scope and to be avoided if you have a weak bladder."
Beautiful ain't. Sally Field may be proclaiming "You like me! You really like me!" behind the camera, but don't be egged on.
