The year is 2013. There is no order. There is no peace. Return to sender. Audience unknown.
As horror films go, this one left me screaming. "Why do they make films like this?!?"
It is to the film's glorious advantage that it does reveal that every cloud, especially the black nimbus of war, has a silver lining and that, indeed, Life Is Beautiful.
movie_title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)

movie_review_blurb: A handful of mesmerizing stories; a film full of hellish, irrational memories; a future filled with hope, of faith in life renewed.
Writer Tina Andrews' 15-year effort to bring this story of an extraordinary individual with a humpty-dumpty-life to the screen pays off big time. Here's one for the ages.
movie_title: Why Do Fools Fall In Love (1998)

movie_review_blurb: A small, poignant gem despite its laggardly pacing. Definitely an off-beat, side show attraction, but with three big rings of heart, character, and soul.
A cure for the wedding bell blues infecting a Polish-American family chock full of moonstruck women and Adonis-featured men.
...an opiate-induced, caffeinated, super-octane trip.
Continuity takes a drubbing and Jackie Chan does his own dubbing in this rerelease of Drunken Master II, a limp Chinese noodle-headed sequel to his 1978 breakthrough feature.

movie_review_blurb: Species II is one sequel that screams...Yuck! It also conjures up...Why? Screenplay be damned. Acting? Throw it out the window.
I don't have to waste my time this weekend or a blank VHS tape. This is not one I care to place in my video library.
Christopher Guest and his well-groomed entourage of improv artists push pseudo dog show mentality to the upper limits of droll wit in Best in Show.
This small, quaint comedy offers up a half-baked fantasy in a lush back-village setting. It's an amiable, unremarkable 92 minutes of wacky, dimwitted characters.
This film isn't apt to light your fire and it's doubtful it will ignite much action at the box-office.
Big, broad, and ballsy, an overstuffed Martin Lawrence looms large in Big Momma's House and appears ready to toss a gross-out shtick at Tom Cruise and M:I-2.

After two grueling hours of slicing and dicing, I hardly savored this time not well spent.
a genuine, heartwarming crowd pleaser, although director Tom Shadyac can be seen disgorging heapings of sentimental claptrap over this biographical landscape.
At times heartwarming home-town kitsch, at other times predictable puppy-love pablum for the young and recently separated, Hope Floats... but just barely.
This latest hockey opus is standard polar fare, Picket Fences on ice, so to speak.
Part sci-fi thriller, part haunting 1940s film noir set piece, Dark City has lots of pizzazz, but too little punch.
...a filmic epiphany.
a touch of Dickens, a spritz of Rube Goldberg, and a dash of Monty Python
Notting Hill is whimsical and light, fresh and quirky. Quite engaging and quietly appealing.
In a year of generally lost expectations, American moviegoers should rejoice in the simple pleasures of A Room for Romeo Brass.
Amerika, here comes Dick. Life with dishonor could never be funnier.
Phooey!
It doesn't work ... at all. Call it Witless or call it Die Hardly.
Family fare. Pure, sweet, and PG-rated.
Star Kid is aimed straight for the youth market and that is probably where it will stay.

This Home Alone clone is genetically spliced with childhood memories of Tom and Jerry.
enough yuks to fill up a funny short subject
Laugh long and prosper.
An entertaining burlesque of The Fugitive. Sit down (watch out for that whoopee cushion!) and enjoy the latest Hollywood sendup of films immemorial.
A streamlined, high gloss, touch-tone remake of the lesser-Hitchcock classic. Harken ye back to the days of rotary dialing.
Head On crashes rights into your gay expectations and drags them down into the gutter. Powerful forces are at work here. You won't go home laughing. No way.
The Negotiator is one of those gloriously unbelievable screenplays and overproduced films that escapist-prone audiences will lap up despite its shortcomings.
There's an old saying: Bless the Child, spare the Audience. And you'd wished the producers thought about this before spending millions on this lame turkey.
Everything is predictable, which is to the detriment of the mostly fine, young talent that appears in this ineffective retread.
For a first feature, Gavin certainly provides plenty of anxiety-inducing moments.

It's nice when so many technical and emotional elements come together in a film. Coco Before Chanel is a hard luck, true life fairy tale story told with poignant humility, embellished with solid acting and determined direction.
Despite the earnest approach from its two stars (who also serve, with Christopher Smith, as producers), there isn't anything fresh in the story.
...a rather interesting tale about a compulsive personality.
Luciferous adeptly blends irritable characters, mesmerizing and unsettling images (and shadows), red herrings, and some harrowing episodes that will disturb.

Lucha Mexico competently captures the nostalgic spectacle of this Mexican sport with vibrant glee. It may be a rambling journey, but it offers up an infectious energy and a behind-the-ropes look at its legendary heroes.

Forget the lame jokes about women drivers. These girls, full of ambition and enthusiasm, just want to have fun! Not everyone can win a race, but Speed Sisters, an amiable 80-minute miracle in the unlikeliest of places, will capture your heart.
Fans of twisted independent cinema might celebrate Aimy in the Cage, and it is a beautiful film to behold, but the damn thing is madder than Alice's Hatter!
The loves and life of Tab Hunter is laid bare, just like his perfect chiseled chest. I can hear his fans swooning.

I can't spot a single thing wrong withBrooklyn. An Oscar-caliber package; start betting on victory for Ronan, at the least. Heart-warming, light-hearted, and perfectly poised. Simple. Beautiful. Lovely.
Lee, who birthed such memorable films asShe's Gotta Have It(1986) and School Daze(1988), is back at the top of his form withChi-Raq. Let's hope he stays there.
The Big Shortis one intense ride. It's a sad, maddening smorgasbord of mean-spirited, indifferent people looking out for their own asse(t)s. Comeuppance is a bitch.

No doubt some out there like the electronic beat that Lough captures. Watching him work has some fascinating moments. His performances are uniquely intense instrumental sessions. Yet, Koenig's music is an acquired taste.
I still remember buying the paperback book Hitchcock/Truffaut.... Fifty years on, it's still one of the most important books any cinephile should own. And, it is, finally, a heck of a movie.
There are too many foot-in-mouth moments rather than clever writing and imaginative directing. The film's narcissistic attitude overplays its welcome.
The slice of life that is Bleak Street is definitely situated on the darker side of the road. It's unquestionably worth visiting for a reality check.
movie_title: Bleak Street (La calle de la amargura) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film's a solid piece of work examining the moral difficulties of war.
Dark, a by-the-numbers thriller of sorts, isn't quite dark enough.
Colliding Dreams cuts to the heart of the controversy in encyclopedic fashion. Consider it the Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Zionism, But Were Afraid to Ask.
If you're looking for a taught spy thriller, don't look for Our Kind of Traitor for nourishment.
The BFG casts a wondrous spell.
In an attempt to meld the pc gaming world with that of modest-budget movie-making, Beta Test doesn't score many points.
As sports-centric films go, those folks looking for cheering crowds on a mild summer's night won't find much joy in The Phenom's mudville. It's a slow walk around the bases.
I love a good skewering, and the serious-funny side of life that is celebrated in Cenedella's oeuvre gets an engaging look-see in this excellent film.
It's a compressed sprawling life's tale of common folk torn by man's intolerance and a family's pain. And an under-nourishing meal.
Playing with pleasure-inducing New Age affirmations in a high tech conspiracy tale is an interesting notion. It doesn't work in Reversion's frame of mind.
... the film's major strength is in Francella's troubling performance as a black-hearted Robin Hood.
Sibylle is a little too arty for its own good.

Spiritual and haunting in its low decibel manner, the New England coming-of-age drama Neptune is an indie effort that follows a young teenager's soul-searching excursion along a disconcerting and sometimes allegorical path.

Fools feels like an unhinged romantic comedy that forgot to take its meds. It's rough and raw, with comedy of a regretful-after-sex variety. Lots of emotional eggshells for the two fragile souls to be fearful of breaking.
The Automate Hate examines with brilliant resonance a decades-long unease within a family.... It's quite the family feud.
As the thrill ride of The Wave coasts back into a predicable finish, it unfortunately drowns in a well of genre convention, gasping for some creative air.
A Country Called Home is a decent enough trip through the back roads of Texas, connecting with a partly dysfunctional family. It's just not something that most viewers will want to write home about.
Dementia be damned - the aging ghosts that haunt Remember are what make it unforgettable.
The New Girlfriend balances comedy and melodrama, while playfully blurring the ever thinning lines between gender and identity.
Pushing yourself to the extreme is what Meru is all about.
...focusing on a more obscure character for many of us, Kempner's tone remains light, brisk, entertaining, instructive, and thoughtful.
It's the writing that sinks Hysteria, and there's no machine that can alleviate that.

George Lucas's last big hurrah is a hackneyed ode to a group of heroes-the Tuskegee Airmen-who deserve better treatment than this cliché interrupted by dazzling, FX-laden dogfights, smoke-filled explosions, boring subplots, and oxygen-depleting dialogue.
Showfolk is best described as an extended public service announcement, and that's probably what the Motion Picture & Television Fund wanted. Something straight arrow and talking head.

It's not often that a self-narrated film has a lasting impression, but Cassio Tolpolar's homegrown and low-key storytelling skills in his documentary Mamaliga Blues offers up an enchanting tale of search and discovery.
Hiden and Irvin make a great statement about how America is enjoying the great craft beer revolution. Drink up!

... despite the best efforts of its cast, Hunting Elephants is a tame comedic excursion into a flimsy world of social lechery and geriatric dysfunction, albeit one that garnered seven Israeli Film Academy Awards nominations.
...the two hours watching such a tepid and lip-synched effort is not a pleasant experience.
... (a) quirky, whimsical life-spanning comedy...
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: ...a marvelous, absorbing, and somewhat intoxicating whole.
An unwavering optimism infuses Radical Grace. It's an inspirational p.s.a promoting faith, hope, and equality, whether you believe in Christ or not.

Depressing as Peace Officer may be, if we can turn Lawrence's belief that a police officer should be a trusted friend and qualified, trained peacemaker, hope might be waiting around the corner for a country filled with trigger-happy authorities.
It's a first-class primer on how political news commentary had its true start. Long before it became something to ridicule on Comedy Central.

In the Alien films, the primal, violence of Giger's bio-mechanical creations cause people to run from the darkness. Dark Star: HR Giger's World beckons you to embrace it, in its own darkly entrancing way.
There's an specious, death-defying maniacal glee afoot in this outlandish outdoors thriller. Big Game is a foreigner's vision of American conspiracy theory run amok.
Russell Crowe's command as a debut director may not be as strong as Clooney's was, but The Water Diviner is a very sincere, inspired-by-true-events effort filled with compassionate performances.

Music and cinema are both universal languages. I can't think of another film that blends the best of these audio and visual worlds into a most enjoyable adventure about mixed cultures and disparate lives that becomes the sum of much more than its parts.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: First time feature director Alex Stapleton does an admirable job educating her viewers on the man who seemingly launched a thousand faces.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's a reason why Woody Allen's screenplays have been nominated for 15 Academy Awards (R). Comic genius, dramatic wit, sharp observation, great characters. With Blue Jasmine, he has taken effete snobbery to glorious heights.
A very impressive jump by Mr. Mills into the big time. He can play misguided as long as he wants. We need the laughs.
Joe Swanberg apparently hasn't stopped mumbling yet.
The best way to enjoy Cop Car is with the windows all the way down. Nice and breezy.
...a personal fever dream...
Cinephiles and history (especially WWII) enthusiasts will find a lot to like in the film. Fans of Fuller (we are legion) will have their appetites lightly whetted.
For all its visual snap, there's no crackle to the story or pop to the characters.
With all its spunk and determination, it's easy to see how close Brave gets to the bull's eye of Pixar perfection.
The only thing amateur about the film are the players, though they are all winners. Meanwhile, They Came to Play inspires in the best documentary fashion.
It's an over-the-top, eye-popping musical that doesn't completely satisfy, especially compared to it's original source classic.
A nicely done piece for such a personal story: harrowing, heroic, and occasionally gripping.
(WIll Gluck) captures today's high school soul with the same resourcefulness as (John) Hughes did in Ferris Beuller's Day Off. It's not quite as endearing, but it's a helluva good start.

The pitch to remake this was probably four words: Gulliver's Travels Jack Black. No adjectives, no adverbs, and, most of all, no imagination. Fox took the bait, and this Christmas there's something smelling rotten under the tree.
What makes Heavy Metal Picnic zip by is how Krulik has taken the original footage and juxtaposed his new material featuring the same characters 20+ years on in their lives.

vibrantly witty and exceptionally delivered

The Damned United will be savored and appreciated when considered for year-end prize consideration. Don't wait till then to see it.

There are problems a-plenty in Vero Beach, Florida, and after watching them dribble forth in the lame ensemble comedy I Do...Until I Don't, I feel that this piece of sunshiny beach would be the last place on earth I'd want to live.

movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

Brazen, shameless, romantic, and broadly funny. With good music. Not Cool is way cool.
